For Man City Slip-Up In Title Race", "body": "Mikel Arteta's Gunners are a single point above Pep Guardiola's men with three games left but City, who host Wolves, crucially have a game in hand.\n\nArsenal resume their quest for Premier League glory against Bournemouth this weekend knowing they have no margin for error with Manchester City hot on their heels.\n\nMikel Arteta's Gunners are a single point above Pep Guardiola's men with three games left but City, who host Wolves, crucially have a game in hand.\n\nNewcastle can pile the pressure on Manchester United in the battle for a Europa League place if they win at Burnley, who are plotting a great escape.\n\nAFP Sport looks at three talking points ahead of the action.\n\nArsenal have hit a rich vein of form since their 2-0 defeat by Aston Villa last month, but are competing against a City side who are now unbeaten in 31 games in all competitions.\n\nThe Gunners have a chance at least to apply some pressure by beating Bournemouth in the early kick-off at the Emirates on Saturday.\n\nBournemouth have registered their highest-ever points tally in a Premier League season to climb to 10th spot but have only beaten Arsenal once before.\n\nCity were not at their best against Nottingham Forest last weekend but still found a way to win and are strong favourites to wrap up an unprecedented fourth straight English title.\n\nArsenal will cling to the hope that Wolves can complete a rare double against City after they won 2-1 at home earlier this season.\n\nGuardiola, for his part, does not believe his side can afford to drop any points in the run-in.\n\n\"With four games left, it's like climbing a mountain,\" he said. \"They are very tough games... If we draw a game, we are not going to win the Premier League. It is what it is.\"\n\nMan Utd seek to stop rot\n\nManchester United's sorry season could plumb new depths unless they kick their costly habit of conceding late goals.\n\nErik ten Hag's chaotic team have won just two of their past nine Premier League matches and have tricky games to come against in-form Crystal Palace, Arsenal and Newcastle, who are their closest rivals for a Europa League spot, before they face Brighton on the final day.\n\nUnited have two potential routes into the Europa League, either by beating Manchester City in the FA Cup final or finishing sixth in the Premier League.\n\nSeventh place could also be enough for UEFA Conference League football next season.\n\nThe Red Devils have never finished below seventh in the Premier League but that is far from certain to remain the case given their poor form.\n\nWest Ham and Chelsea are within striking distance but have been hampered by their own inconsistency in recent months.\n\nBurnley's escape attempt\n\nBurnley appeared dead and buried just weeks ago but they have lost just one of their past eight league games to remain in the battle for survival.\n\nVincent Kompany's team are still second from bottom of the table but are just two points from safety with three matches to play.\n\nThe first of those is at Turf Moor against Eddie Howe's Newcastle, who have lost 10 times on the road this season.\n\nBurnley's final game is on May 19 against Forest, currently one place above the drop zone, and Kompany wants his team to be still alive when the teams meet.\n\n\"For us, the biggest thing is, can we give ourselves a game against Forest where we have something to look forward to?\" said the Belgian.\n\n\"We don't need much more. We just want that opportunity on that one day. That's enough for us to rally to something special.\"\n\nForest will hope to pull away from the danger zone when they travel to already relegated Sheffield United.\n\nArsenal v Bournemouth (1130), "title": "Premier League leaders Arsenal hope for Man City slip-up in title race", "body": "Arsenal resume their quest for Premier League glory against Bournemouth this weekend knowing they have no margin for error with Manchester City hot on their heels.\n\nMikel Arteta's Gunners are a single point above Pep Guardiola's men with three games left but City, who host Wolves, crucially have a game in hand.\n\nNewcastle can pile the pressure on Manchester United in the battle for a Europa League place if they win at Burnley, who are plotting a great escape.\n\nAFP Sport looks at three talking points ahead of the action.\n\nCan Wolves stop City juggernaut?\n\nArsenal have hit a rich vein of form since their 2-0 defeat by Aston Villa last month, but are competing against a City side who are now unbeaten in 31 games in all competitions.\n\nThe Gunners have a chance at least to apply some pressure by beating Bournemouth in the early kick-off at the Emirates on Saturday.\n\nBournemouth have registered their highest-ever points tally in a Premier League season to climb to 10th spot but have only beaten Arsenal once before.\n\nCity were not at their best against Nottingham Forest last weekend but still found a way to win and are strong favourites to wrap up an unprecedented fourth straight English title.\n\nArsenal will cling to the hope that Wolves can complete a rare double against City after they won 2-1 at home earlier this season.\n\nGuardiola, for his part, does not believe his side can afford to drop any points in the run-in.\n\n\"With four games left, it's like climbing a mountain,\" he said. \"They are very tough games... If we draw a game, we are not going to win the Premier League. It is what it is.\"\n\nMan Utd seek to stop rot\n\nManchester United's sorry season could plumb new depths unless they kick their costly habit of conceding late goals.\n\nErik ten Hag's chaotic team have won just two of their past nine Premier League matches and have tricky games to come against in-form Crystal Palace, Arsenal and Newcastle, who are their closest rivals for a Europa League spot, before they face Brighton on the final day.\n\nUnited have two potential routes into the Europa League, either by beating Manchester City in the FA Cup final or finishing sixth in the Premier League.\n\nSeventh place could also be enough for UEFA Conference League football next season.\n\nThe Red Devils have never finished below seventh in the Premier League but that is far from certain to remain the case given their poor form.\n\nWest Ham and Chelsea are within striking distance but have been hampered by their own inconsistency in recent months.\n\nMore from this section Uruguay's leftist icon Jose Mujica has cancer: doctor Labour claims victory in key council as Sunak braced for local election nightmare MLB Angels star Trout to have left knee surgery Burnley's escape attempt\n\nBurnley appeared dead and buried just weeks ago but they have lost just one of their past eight league games to remain in the battle for survival.\n\nVincent Kompany's team are still second from bottom of the table but are just two points from safety with three matches to play.\n\nThe first of those is at Turf Moor against Eddie Howe's Newcastle, who have lost 10 times on the road this season.\n\nBurnley's final game is on May 19 against Forest, currently one place above the drop zone, and Kompany wants his team to be still alive when the teams meet.\n\n\"For us, the biggest thing is, can we give ourselves a game against Forest where we have something to look forward to?\" said the Belgian.\n\n\"We don't need much more. We just want that opportunity on that one day. That's enough for us to rally to something special.\"\n\nForest will hope to pull away from the danger zone when they travel to already relegated Sheffield United.\n\nFixtures\n\nFriday (1900 GMT)\n\nLuton v Everton\n\nSaturday (1400 unless stated)\n\nArsenal v Bournemouth (1130), Brentford v Fulham, Burnley v Newcastle, Sheffield United v Nottingham Forest, Manchester City v Wolves {"uri": "8110174404", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "19:22:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T19:22:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T19:22:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/sports/title-relegation-and-european-spots-in-the-balance-as-premier-league-heads-for-exciting-finale/articleshow/109825553.cms", "title": "Title, relegation and European spots in the balance as Premier League heads for exciting finale", "body": "The Premier League title race is down to Arsenal and Manchester City, with Arsenal leading by one point. European qualification spots are almost settled, with Aston Villa likely joining Arsenal, City, and Liverpool in the Champions League. The race for Europa Conference League spots is tight, with Manchester United, Newcastle, and Chelsea vying for sixth and seventh places. The relegation battle involves Nottingham Forest, Luton, and Burnley, with two spots to avoid.The title race is down to two teams.\n\nThe relegation tussle still involves three.\n\nAnd the contest for the remaining European qualification positions contains as many as five.\n\nThe Premier League season is down to its last two weeks and there's still plenty at stake from top to bottom.\n\nMeanwhile, the second-tier Championship's regular season finishes on Saturday, with a second automatic promotion spot set to be secured.\n\nHere's a look at what's still to be decided:\n\nTitle\n\nThis time, Arsenal vs. Manchester City for the Premier League title looks like going down to the wire.\n\nCity took advantage of a late-season collapse by the Gunners to win the league with three matches to spare in the 2022-23 campaign, but an improved Arsenal might last the course this time round.\n\nArsenal leads by one point with three games to go - against Bournemouth at home on Saturday, Manchester United away and Everton at home. City has four games remaining - at home to Wolverhampton, away to Fulham and Tottenham, and at home to West Ham - and would capture an unprecedented fourth straight title by winning all of them.\n\nThe pressure is on the defending champions to do that because even just one draw could be fatal. Arsenal has a superior goal difference and, as it stands, would win on that tiebreaker if the teams are equal on points.\n\nAway to Tottenham looks to be the toughest match for City, which has yet to win - or even score - in four league games at Tottenham's new stadium that opened in 2019. Spurs fans will have mixed feelings about the May 14 game, because a win for their team could hand Arsenal, Tottenham's fierce north London rival, the title.\n\nA trip to Old Trafford is likely Arsenal's hardest remaining fixture. After all, Liverpool - until recently the other title contender - saw its season turned upside down after a loss at United in the FA Cup quarterfinals on March 17 was followed by a costly draw at Old Trafford in the league on April 7.\n\nThe Premier League is the only one of Europe's top five leagues where the title race is still bubbling. Germany's Bundesliga (champions Bayer Leverkusen), Italy's Serie A (Inter Milan) and France's Ligue 1 (Paris Saint-Germain) have been decided, while Real Madrid leads Barcelona by 11 points in Spain's La Liga.\n\nEuropean places\n\nArsenal, City and Liverpool are locks for Champions League qualification, with fourth-place Aston Villa likely to join them. Tottenham is isolated in fifth, the reward for which is Europa League qualification.\n\nThe remaining intrigue, then, revolves around which teams finishes in sixth and seventh to likely earn a berth in the Europa Conference League. Manchester United, Newcastle and Chelsea are the teams occupying sixth to eighth places and three points separate them with four games left for each. West Ham and Bournemouth have outside shots in ninth and 10th, respectively.\n\nChelsea is in the best form, having lost just one of its last 11 games - though that was 5-0 at Arsenal.\n\nIf United drops to eighth, the team has a last chance to get into Europe by winning the FA Cup final against Man City a week after the Premier League finishes.\n\nRelegation\n\nThe relegation battle looks like it will go to the final day of the season - and won't just be determined by what happens on the field.\n\nWith last-place Sheffield United already down, there are three teams fighting to avoid the two remaining relegation places: Nottingham Forest (26 points), Luton (25 points) and Burnley (24 points).\n\nEach team has three games left and, significantly, two of them meet in the final round when Burnley hosts Forest.\n\nForest's current points total is subject to change, however, because the club has appealed against a four-point deduction for breaching the league's financial rules. The result of that appeal should be known before the end of the season, meaning Forest could recover some points based on the views of an independent panel.\n\nIf Burnley and Luton are also relegated, it means the three teams that came up last year lasted just one season before going back down to the Championship.\n\nPromotion\n\nThere's one automatic promotion spot up for grabs heading into the final round of games in the second-tier Championship on Saturday.\n\nLeicester has already clinched promotion and an immediate return to the Premier League. The team will go up as champions.\n\nIpswich or Leeds will join them.\n\nIpswich, which last played in the top flight in 2002, is currently in second place and three points ahead of third-place Leeds, whose American ownership group includes major-winning golfers Jordan Spieth and Justin Thomas.\n\nIpswich hosts next-to-last Huddersfield, and Leeds is at home to fourth-place Southampton.\n\nThe teams placed third to sixth will compete in the playoffs for the third promotion spot. The playoff final is at Wembley Stadium on May 26.", "source": {"uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Economic Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "Mikel Arteta's Gunners are a single point above Pep Guardiola's men with three games left but City, who host Wolves, crucially have a game in hand.\n\nArsenal resume their quest for Premier League glory against Bournemouth this weekend knowing they have no margin for error with Manchester City hot on their heels.\n\nMikel Arteta's Gunners are a single point above Pep Guardiola's men with three games left but City, who host Wolves, crucially have a game in hand.\n\nNewcastle can pile the pressure on Manchester United in the battle for a Europa League place if they win at Burnley, who are plotting a great escape.\n\nAFP Sport looks at three talking points ahead of the action.\n\nCAN WOLVES STOP CITY JUGGERNAUT?\n\nArsenal have hit a rich vein of form since their 2-0 defeat by Aston Villa last month, but are competing against a City side who are now unbeaten in 31 games in all competitions.\n\nThe Gunners have a chance at least to apply some pressure by beating Bournemouth in the early kick-off at the Emirates on Saturday.\n\nBournemouth have registered their highest-ever points tally in a Premier League season to climb to 10th spot but have only beaten Arsenal once before.\n\nCity were not at their best against Nottingham Forest last weekend but still found a way to win and are strong favourites to wrap up an unprecedented fourth straight English title.\n\nArsenal will cling to the hope that Wolves can complete a rare double against City after they won 2-1 at home earlier this season.\n\nGuardiola, for his part, does not believe his side can afford to drop any points in the run-in.\n\n\"With four games left, it's like climbing a mountain,\" he said. \"They are very tough games... If we draw a game, we are not going to win the Premier League. It is what it is.\"\n\nMAN UTD SEEK TO STOP ROT\n\nManchester United's sorry season could plumb new depths unless they kick their costly habit of conceding late goals.\n\nErik ten Hag's chaotic team have won just two of their past nine Premier League matches and have tricky games to come against in-form Crystal Palace, Arsenal and Newcastle, who are their closest rivals for a Europa League spot, before they face Brighton on the final day.\n\nUnited have two potential routes into the Europa League, either by beating Manchester City in the FA Cup final or finishing sixth in the Premier League.\n\nSeventh place could also be enough for Uefa Conference League football next season.\n\nThe Red Devils have never finished below seventh in the Premier League but that is far from certain to remain the case given their poor form.\n\nWest Ham and Chelsea are within striking distance but have been hampered by their own inconsistency in recent months.\n\nBURNLEY'S ESCAPE ATTEMPT\n\nBurnley appeared dead and buried just weeks ago but they have lost just one of their past eight league games to remain in the battle for survival.\n\nVincent Kompany's team are still second from bottom of the table but are just two points from safety with three matches to play.\n\nThe first of those is at Turf Moor against Eddie Howe's Newcastle, who have lost 10 times on the road this season.\n\nBurnley's final game is on May 19 against Forest, currently one place above the drop zone, and Kompany wants his team to be still alive when the teams meet.\n\n\"For us, the biggest thing is, can we give ourselves a game against Forest where we have something to look forward to?\" said the Belgian.\n\n\"We don't need much more. We just want that opportunity on that one day. That's enough for us to rally to something special.\"\n\nForest will hope to pull away from the danger zone when they travel to already relegated Sheffield United.", "source": {"uri": "tbsnews.net", after Arsenal & Man City wins", "body": "Gary Neville 'fears' the title race will be decided before the final day of the season as he tipped Manchester City to be crowned Premier League champions ahead of Arsenal.\n\nArsenal, searching for their first league title since 2004, remain one point ahead of Man City following Saturday's victory over Bournemouth, but now have just two more games remaining.\n\nCity have three more fixtures to play meaning they will win the title for a record fourth successive season if they take maximum points from Fulham, Tottenham and West Ham.\n\nFans and pundits have been dreaming of a final-day shootout for the title but Neville believes Arsenal's challenge could be ended when they travel to Old Trafford next week.\n\nManchester United have struggled for consistency this season but are more than capable of producing surprise results, having knocked Liverpool out of the FA Cup and taken Premier League points off Jurgen Klopp's side last month.\n\nLiverpool can still mathematically win the title but will need to win their next two games and hope for an unexpected meltdown from both Man City and Arsenal to lift the Premier League in Klopp's final season at Anfield.\n\nAssessing the title race after the weekend results, Neville said on his Sky Sports podcast: 'A few weeks ago when I said Arsenal had to be perfect and they have just had that one slip-up against Aston Villa, there's an inevitability of City at this stage of the season, getting the job done, knowing what they need to do.\n\n'They have got that difficult game against Spurs on paper in 10 days but the way Spurs are at this moment in time I think it will be difficult for them against a City side playing for the title, it will be a difficult proposition.\n\n'As I sit here this weekend, Arsenal and City played really well and did their jobs but you wonder where the title race is going to twist. Where is the twist? City don't give you twists.\n\n'You always said in years gone by, there will be a twist and turn, something will happen, I'm not sure it is going to happen. What normally happens in these moments is if City win on the Saturday, Arsenal drop points on the Sunday and City win the title on the Tuesday.\n\n'That's what normally happens. It may go to the final day and if it does then it means Arsenal have beaten Man United at Old Trafford. If Arsenal go win at Old Trafford that's a hell of a win.\n\n'I have that fear the title race could be over a week on Tuesday. I want the title race to go to the final day, my fear is it won't if City win on Saturday against Fulham and United take points off Arsenal on the Sunday.\n\n'Arsenal have already proven they are a different side than last season but just feels like an inevitability City will be perfect until the end.'\n\nThe Gunners visit Old Trafford on Sunday afternoon before finishing their 2023-24 campaign at home to Everton. It is what it is.\"\n\nMAN UTD SEEK TO STOP ROT\n\nManchester United's sorry season could plumb new depths unless they kick their costly habit of conceding late goals.\n\nErik ten Hag's chaotic team have won just two of their past nine Premier League matches and have tricky games to come against in-form Crystal Palace, Arsenal and Newcastle, who are their closest rivals for a Europa League spot, before they face Brighton on the final day.\n\nUnited have two potential routes into the Europa League, either by beating Manchester City in the FA Cup final or finishing sixth in the Premier League.\n\nSeventh place could also be enough for Uefa Conference League football next season.\n\nThe Red Devils have never finished below seventh in the Premier League, but that is far from certain to remain the case given their poor form. West Ham and Chelsea are within striking distance but have been hampered by their own inconsistency in recent months.\n\nBURNLEY's ESCAPE ATTEMPT\n\nBurnley appeared dead and buried just weeks ago, but they have lost just one of their past eight league games to remain in the battle for survival.\n\nVincent Kompany's team are still second from bottom of the table, but are just two points from safety with three matches to play.\n\nThe first of those is at Turf Moor against Eddie Howe's Newcastle, who have lost 10 times on the road this season.\n\nBurnley's final game is on May 19 against Forest, currently one place above the drop zone, and Kompany wants his team to be still alive when the teams meet.\n\n\"For us, the biggest thing is, can we give ourselves a game against Forest where we have something to look forward to?\" said the Belgian.\n\n\"We don't need much more. {"uri": "8109230845", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "08:01:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T08:01:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T08:01:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/2926256-premier-league-season-concludes-with-dramatic-final-day-deciding-fate-of-title-relegation-and-european-contenders", "title": "Premier League Season Concludes with Dramatic Final Day Deciding Fate of Title, Relegation, and European Contenders | Sports-Games", "body": "The Premier League title race comes down to Arsenal and Manchester City, while the relegation battle remains tense between Nottingham Forest, Luton Town, and Burnley. Arsenal leads by a point with three games remaining, while Manchester City has four games left. The contest for the remaining European qualification positions involves Manchester United, Newcastle, and Chelsea. The Championship's regular season concludes Saturday, with Ipswich Town and Leeds United vying for the second automatic promotion spot. Sheffield United is already relegated, and the three teams that came up last year (Burnley, Luton, and Forest) face relegation concerns, with Forest's points subject to change due to a financial rule breach appeal.\n\nThe title race is down to two teams. The relegation tussle still involves three. And, the contest for the remaining European qualification positions contains as many as five.\n\nThe Premier League season is down to its last two weeks and there's still plenty at stake from top to bottom.\n\nMeanwhile, the second-tier Championship's regular season finishes on Saturday, with a second automatic promotion spot set to be secured.\n\nHere's a look at what's still to be decided: TITLE This time, Arsenal vs Manchester City for the Premier League title looks like going down to the wire.\n\nCity took advantage of a late-season collapse by the Gunners to win the league with three matches to spare in the 2022-23 campaign, but an improved Arsenal might last the course this time round.\n\nArsenal leads by a point with three games to go -- against Bournemouth at home on Saturday, Manchester United away and Everton at home.\n\nCity has four games remaining -- at home to Wolverhampton Wanderers, away to Fulham and Tottenham Hotspur, and at home to West Ham United -- and would capture an unprecedented fourth straight title by winning all of them.\n\nThe pressure is on the defending champion to do that because even just a draw could be fatal. Arsenal has a superior goal difference and, as it stands, would win on that tiebreaker if the teams are equal on points.\n\nAway to Tottenham looks to be the toughest match for City, which has yet to win -- or even score -- in four league games at Tottenham's new stadium that opened in 2019. Spurs fans will have mixed feelings about the May 14 game, because a win for their team could hand Arsenal, Tottenham's fierce north London rival, the title.\n\nA trip to Old Trafford is likely Arsenal's hardest remaining fixture. After all, Liverpool -- until recently the other title contender -- saw its season turned upside down after a loss at United in the FA Cup quarterfinals on March 17 was followed by a costly draw at Old Trafford in the league on April 7.\n\nThe Premier League is the only one of Europe's top five leagues where the title race is still bubbling. Germany's Bundesliga (champions Bayer Leverkusen), Italy's Serie A (Inter Milan) and France's Ligue 1 (Paris Saint-Germain) have been decided, while Real Madrid leads Barcelona by 11 points in Spain's La Liga.\n\nEUROPEAN PLACES Arsenal, City and Liverpool are locked for Champions League qualification, with fourth-place Aston Villa likely to join them. Tottenham is isolated in fifth, the reward for which is Europa League qualification. The remaining intrigue, then, revolves around which teams finish in sixth and seventh to likely earn a berth in the Europa Conference League.\n\nManchester United, Newcastle and Chelsea are the teams occupying sixth to eighth places and three points separate them with four games left for each. West Ham and Bournemouth have outside shots in ninth and 10th, respectively.\n\nChelsea is in the best form, having lost just one of its last 11 games -- though that was 5-0 at Arsenal.\n\nIf United drops to eighth, the team has a last chance to get into Europe by winning the FA Cup final against Man City a week after the Premier League finishes.\n\nRELEGATION The relegation battle looks like it will go to the final day of the season -- and won't just be determined by what happens on the field.\n\nWith last-place Sheffield United already down, three teams are fighting to avoid the two remaining relegation places: Nottingham Forest (26 points), Luton Town (25 points) and Burnley (24 points).\n\nEach team has three games left and, significantly, two of them meet in the final round when Burnley hosts Forest.\n\nForest's current points total is subject to change, however, because the club has appealed against a four-point deduction for breaching the league's financial rules. The result of that appeal should be known before the end of the season, meaning Forest could recover some points based on the views of an independent panel.\n\nIf Burnley and Luton are also relegated, it means the three teams that came up last year lasted just a season before going back down to the Championship.\n\nPROMOTION There's one automatic promotion spot up for grabs heading into the final round of games in the second-tier Championship on Saturday.\n\nLeicester City has already clinched promotion and an immediate return to the Premier League. The team will go up as champions. Ipswich Town or Leeds United will join them.\n\nIpswich, which last played in the top flight in 2002, is currently in second place and three points ahead of third-place Leeds, whose American ownership group includes major-winning golfers Jordan Spieth and Justin Thomas.\n\nIpswich hosts next-to-last Huddersfield Town, and Leeds is at home to fourth-place Southampton.\n\nThe teams placed third to sixth will compete in the playoffs for the third promotion spot. The playoff final is at Wembley Stadium on May 26.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", {"uri": "8112657849", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "18:04:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T18:04:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T18:04:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/man-city-title-verdict-clear-29117832", "title": "Man City title verdict clear after Arsenal sent 'ominous' warning", "body": "Manchester City ramped up the pressure on Arsenal on Saturday evening after producing a commanding display against Wolves.\n\nWinning 5-1 on home soil, Pep Guardiola's side moved back to within one point of the Gunners as Erling Haaland enjoyed another memorable day in a City shirt.\n\nArsenal had done their bit on Saturday, beating Bournemouth 3-0 at Emirates Stadium, though the Sky Blues are refusing to back down as they bid to secure a fourth successive Premier League crown. It remains to be seem which club will come out on top in the next fortnight, with any slip-up likely to be punished.\n\nOffering their thoughts on the weekend's action and what it means for the title race, the thoughts of the national media can be found below.\n\nREAD MORE: What Phil Foden did after Pep Guardiola tantrum proves point in front of Man City legend David Silva\n\nREAD MORE: I fell out with Pep Guardiola and Erik ten Hag - but every Manchester United fan is talking about me\n\n'Pushed to the edge'\n\nMiguel Delaney of The Independent wrote:\n\n\"A scoreline that would have been predicted, but from a match that shredded nerves. Arsenal may not know if they will be Premier League champions, but they certainly know what it's like to be pushed to the edge in a run-in. Bournemouth more than did their bit in a 3-0 Arsenal win that, for the moment, puts them four points clear of Manchester City but with two more games played.\n\n\"The expectation that Pep Guardiola's team would go and win their four remaining matches hung over everything, especially Bukayo Saka's 45th-minute penalty. If you wanted a scene to capture the deepest tension in a stadium, this was it. Saka rolled it in to bring relief but not yet total release. Andoni Iraola's Bournemouth made Arsenal do much more.\n\n\"There was still that immersive tension about the occasion, Arsenal aware that any slip could bring back so many agonising memories from last season.\n\n\"As for the title, they're now in another nervously exciting situation. They have to watch two Manchester City matches before going to Old Trafford next week for a game that will be enlivened by so many narratives, and some high stakes.\n\n\"It might well come down to that. This season could yet end as everyone predicted but it already looks like it will shred every nerve until then.\"\n\n'Hard to back against the champions'\n\nJames Ducker of The Telegraph wrote:\n\n\"Arsenal have been good - oh so good this season - but they must worry City are simply not going to falter over the next fortnight. Liverpool know only too well how that feels and there were certainly no signs of City slipping up here against Wolves, not with Haaland in wrecking mode.\n\n\"And so, regardless of what Arsenal do over the next couple of weeks, the title will be headed back to the Etihad if City beat Fulham and Tottenham away and West Ham at home on the final day. It is hard to back against the champions, all the more so when Haaland is taking it upon himself to play like this.\"\n\n'It was ominous for Arsenal'\n\nJonathan Northcroft of The Times wrote:\n\n\"It still looks tight, still looks like a who-blinks-first affair where a single misstep is likely to cost the side who makes it. City's manager certainly wants his players to think in those terms. Three games, three wins and you're champions. Anything less, it is Arsenal's prize.\n\n\"You suspect he is correct. The lesson of a rare Saturday on which both contenders were playing is that neither look at all prone to faltering. Both scored handsome wins against decent and potentially awkward opponents. On this form, you would expect a City victory in their next game, away to Fulham.\n\n\"Perhaps it was ominous for Arsenal that Guardiola was not especially happy with his team's performance despite winning 5-1, and that Erling Haaland was not overjoyed about coming off after his four-goal haul.\n\n\"Both want more. It is why Haaland has a clear lead once again in the Golden Boot contest, and why Guardiola is pushing City towards something unprecedented -- the achievement of being the first team in history to win four consecutive English league titles.\n\n\"If anything can stop a City side that hasn't lost in the league since early December, it could be a visit to Tottenham. Then again, if any place can derail Arsenal, Old Trafford might. We're set for quite the last week.\"\n\n'Needing an unlikely snooker'\n\nJack Gaughan of The Daily Mail wrote:\n\n\"And City are in the mood, 24 goals in their last six league games since a drab draw against Arsenal that seemed to hand the title advantage over to both the Gunners and Liverpool. Now it's in City's hands and, given the way in which Wolves appeared beaten from the off, Arsenal will be praying that they are not relying on favours come the last day.\n\n\"So this title race - violently swinging from the best ever to boring in the court of public opinion once City clicked into gear - hinges on a couple of consecutive away matches for City.\n\n\"Fulham on Saturday before the dreaded trip to Tottenham three days later. Although winning there in the FA Cup four months ago broke their hoodoo, City have still yet to score a Premier League goal at the new stadium. Even a broken Spurs is a tricky Spurs for the champions.\n\n\"Guardiola is insistent that they must win all three games - which would mean nine straight victories, their longest run since this time last year - to clinch another crown. He is adamant Arsenal will not drop further points, predicting that they beat Manchester United and Everton.\n\n\"If that transpires then Spurs and Fulham are the games, they are the title race.\n\n\"The away record is improved this year, City chalking up 37 points from 17 games - one more than all of last season - but these are two grounds where they were made to work. Julian Alvarez dug out a wonder goal to seal a win at Craven Cottage in the run-in, while Spurs have always had something over them. It's by no means done but come out the other side of those and Arsenal will be left needing an unlikely snooker or two.\"", "source": {"uri": "manchestereveningnews.co.uk", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8109217683", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "07:50:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T07:50:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T07:50:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://english.aawsat.com/node/4998036", "title": "Title, Relegation and European Spots in the Balance as Premier League Heads for Exciting Finale", "body": "Manchester City's Jack Grealish celebrates with the trophy after winning the 2022 English Premier League title at the Etihad Stadium in Manchester, England, Sunday, May 22, 2022. (AP)\n\nAnd the contest for the remaining European qualification positions contains as many as five.\n\nThe Premier League season is down to its last two weeks and there's still plenty at stake from top to bottom.\n\nMeanwhile, the second-tier Championship's regular season finishes on Saturday, with a second automatic promotion spot set to be secured.\n\nThis time, Arsenal vs. Manchester City for the Premier League title looks like going down to the wire.\n\nCity took advantage of a late-season collapse by the Gunners to win the league with three matches to spare in the 2022-23 campaign, but an improved Arsenal might last the course this time round.\n\nArsenal leads by one point with three games to go -- against Bournemouth at home on Saturday, Manchester United away and Everton at home.\n\nCity has four games remaining -- at home to Wolverhampton, away to Fulham and Tottenham, and at home to West Ham -- and would capture an unprecedented fourth straight title by winning all of them.\n\nThe pressure is on the defending champions to do that because even just one draw could be fatal. Arsenal has a superior goal difference and, as it stands, would win on that tiebreaker if the teams are equal on points.\n\nAway to Tottenham looks to be the toughest match for City, which has yet to win -- or even score -- in four league games at Tottenham's new stadium that opened in 2019. Spurs fans will have mixed feelings about the May 14 game, because a win for their team could hand Arsenal, Tottenham's fierce north London rival, the title.\n\nA trip to Old Trafford is likely Arsenal's hardest remaining fixture. After all, Liverpool -- until recently the other title contender -- saw its season turned upside down after a loss at United in the FA Cup quarterfinals on March 17 was followed by a costly draw at Old Trafford in the league on April 7.\n\nThe Premier League is the only one of Europe's top five leagues where the title race is still bubbling. Germany's Bundesliga (champions Bayer Leverkusen), Italy's Serie A (Inter Milan) and France's Ligue 1 (Paris Saint-Germain) have been decided, while Real Madrid leads Barcelona by 11 points in Spain's La Liga.\n\nEUROPEAN PLACES\n\nArsenal, City and Liverpool are locks for Champions League qualification, with fourth-place Aston Villa likely to join them. Tottenham is isolated in fifth, the reward for which is Europa League qualification.\n\nThe remaining intrigue, then, revolves around which teams finishes in sixth and seventh to likely earn a berth in the Europa Conference League. Manchester United, Newcastle and Chelsea are the teams occupying sixth to eighth places and three points separate them with four games left for each. West Ham and Bournemouth have outside shots in ninth and 10th, respectively.\n\nChelsea is in the best form, having lost just one of its last 11 games -- though that was 5-0 at Arsenal.\n\nIf United drops to eighth, the team has a last chance to get into Europe by winning the FA Cup final against Man City a week after the Premier League finishes.\n\nRELEGATION\n\nThe relegation battle looks like it will go to the final day of the season -- and won't just be determined by what happens on the field.\n\nWith last-place Sheffield United already down, there are three teams fighting to avoid the two remaining relegation places: Nottingham Forest (26 points), Luton (25 points) and Burnley (24 points).\n\nEach team has three games left and, significantly, two of them meet in the final round when Burnley hosts Forest.\n\nForest's current points total is subject to change, however, because the club has appealed against a four-point deduction for breaching the league's financial rules. The result of that appeal should be known before the end of the season, meaning Forest could recover some points based on the views of an independent panel.\n\nIf Burnley and Luton are also relegated, it means the three teams that came up last year lasted just one season before going back down to the Championship.\n\nPROMOTION\n\nThere's one automatic promotion spot up for grabs heading into the final round of games in the second-tier Championship on Saturday.\n\nLeicester has already clinched promotion and an immediate return to the Premier League. The team will go up as champions.\n\nIpswich or Leeds will join them.\n\nIpswich, which last played in the top flight in 2002, is currently in second place and three points ahead of third-place Leeds, whose American ownership group includes major-winning golfers Jordan Spieth and Justin Thomas.\n\nIpswich hosts next-to-last Huddersfield, and Leeds is at home to fourth-place Southampton.\n\nThe teams placed third to sixth will compete in the playoffs for the third promotion spot. If City slip up, Arsenal could overtake them with two wins from their last two games, so the Blues will hope to get a favour from rivals Manchester United next Sunday when Arsenal visit Old Trafford.\n\nWhile Pep Guardiola's side are in a position of strength, they know what will happen if they drop their standards, with the margins as fine as any of their previous title races under the manager. They only need to look at an incredible weekend of WSL action to see how quickly things can change.\n\nALSO READ: How Arsenal are helping Man City in Premier League title race\n\nALSO READ: Roy Keane's latest attack shows Erling Haaland is doing something right at Man City\n\nGareth Taylor's City Women have been excellent this season, and looked like they had finally found a way to break Chelsea's hold on the Women's Super League title. With Emma Hayes' Chelsea losing to Liverpool last week, City knew that four points from their final two games would crown them champions, but a home clash with Arsenal on Sunday was not a simple fixture.\n\nIt was all going well, with the Blues leading 1-0 as injury time loomed, but an 89th-minute equaliser from Stina Blackstenius set up a nervy ending, and the Swede's 94th-minute winner turned the title race on its head. Chelsea, six points behind with an extra game to play, were suddenly back in the running. Of course it had to be Arsenal, as well.\n\nChelsea were still seven goals behind City when it came to goal difference, so they not only had to win on Sunday, win their game in hand, and win on the final day, but also better City's goal difference in the space of those three games. They went out and beat Bristol City 8-0 to complete a nightmare day for City.\n\nChelsea now just need to win their final two games, while matching City's goal difference at Aston Villa - who they historically struggle against - to retain their title. City have gone from one hand on the trophy to relying on help from Tottenham and United, who Chelsea play this week.\n\nSo just like in the Premier League, City will be hoping for United to slow down their title rivals in the final week. If United beat Chelsea in the WSL and Arsenal in the Premier League, both at Old Trafford, they could face a situation where they hand the Blues two titles in a matter of days.\n\n\"All the staff and the fans know it. One mistake and you will not win the Premier League,\" said Pep Guardiola after the Wolves game. \"The players know that if we don't win, ciao ciao, bye-bye.\n\n\"You see the level of consistency with Arsenal but you smell they are not going to lose the two games they have. It's going to be easy? No, but it's in our hands.\"\n\nCity Women have shown how easily that control can slip away in the space of five minutes, and the fact that it was Arsenal inflicting that blow will encourage the Gunners in the Premier League too. {"uri": "8113791341", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "12:34:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T12:34:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T12:34:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.football.london/arsenal-fc/news/gary-neville-explains-new-man-29120058", "title": "Gary Neville explains new Man City title timeline with brutal Arsenal verdict", "body": "Gary Neville is worried that the title race will be decided before the final day of the season despite Arsenal continuing to push Manchester City all the way. For the fourth week in a row both sides were victorious, leaving things as they have been, a single point gap at the top.\n\nMikel Arteta's side once more went first, beating Bournemouth 3-0 in comfortable style, but were never truly given much belief that City would be unable to match their result. Erling Haaland scored four in a 5-1 win for Pep Guardiola's side just hours later to leave it as they were.\n\nNow, with just two games to go, three for City, Neville can't see a way that the champions drop points. Although they do travel to Tottenham next week in the toughest remaining match, four defeats in a row for Ange Postecoglou's side has left very little to play for.\n\nSpurs were beaten 4-2 by Liverpool on Sunday having gone 4-0 down shortly after half-time. Speaking on commentary Neville said he wasn't confident that Tottenham would be able to do their rivals a helping hand. \"I think Arsenal fans, coaches and players, if you were looking at this Tottenham team and thinking can they somehow raise their game for that game a week on Tuesday, it is looking doubtful as you see them now in front of you,\" he said.\n\nOn his Sky Sports podcast after the match he continued: \"That's the problem. A few weeks ago I said they [Arsenal] would have to be perfect and they have just had that one slip up didn't they, against Aston Villa. There's an inevitability to City isn't there at this stage of the season, getting the job done and doing what they need to do.\n\n\"They have got that difficult game at Spurs on paper in 10 days but the way that Spurs are at this moment in time I think it'll be difficult for them. A City that's playing for the title is a very different proposition and as I sit here this weekend, Arsenal played really well, did their job.\n\nREAD MORE: Triple Arsenal title boost hope remains as Man City face unlikely Premier League challenge\n\nREAD MORE: Gary Neville fires Arsenal brand new Premier League title message as new Man City truth clear\n\n\"City played really well and did their job but you're wondering where the title race is going to twist. City don't give you the twists. You always said in the years gone by that there will be a twist and a turn, that something happens. I'm not sure it is going to happen.\"\n\nCity play first next weekend and can move back to the top of the league, albeit briefly with Arsenal going to Manchester United one day later. Neville thinks that it could be all over by the time Arsenal get to welcoming Everton on the final day.\n\n\"What normally happens in these moments, normally happens, is that if City win on the Saturday [against Fulham], Arsenal drop points on the Sunday and City win the title on the Tuesday [against Tottenham]. That's what normally happens, in my experience of these title races.\n\n\"You think, it's going to go down to the final day,' it may go down to the final day and if it went down to the final day that means that Arsenal have gone and beaten Manchester United at Old Trafford. We can laugh and we can giggle about how Manchester United have been but Arsenal going to Old Trafford and winning, that's going to be a hell of a win.\n\n\"I have that fear that the title could be over a week on Tuesday when in terms of a neutral, I want the title to go to the final day obviously. {"uri": "2024-05-344452674", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "22:25:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T22:25:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T22:00:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://dailytimes.com.pk/1191664/premier-league-heads-for-exciting-finale-title-relegation-and-european-spots-in-the-balance/", "title": "Premier League heads for exciting finale: Title, relegation and European spots in the balance", "body": "This time, Arsenal vs. Manchester City for the Premier League title looks like going down to the wire.\n\nCity took advantage of a late-season collapse by the Gunners to win the league with three matches to spare in the 2022-23 campaign, but an improved Arsenal might last the course this time round.\n\nArsenal leads by one point with three games to go - against Bournemouth at home on Saturday, Manchester United away and Everton at home. City has four games remaining - at home to Wolverhampton, away to Fulham and Tottenham, and at home to West Ham - and would capture an unprecedented fourth straight title by winning all of them.\n\nThe pressure is on the defending champions to do that because even just one draw could be fatal. Arsenal has a superior goal difference and, as it stands, would win on that tiebreaker if the teams are equal on points.\n\nAway to Tottenham looks to be the toughest match for City, which has yet to win - or even score - in four league games at Tottenham's new stadium that opened in 2019. Spurs fans will have mixed feelings about the May 14 game, because a win for their team could hand Arsenal, Tottenham's fierce north London rival, the title.\n\nA trip to Old Trafford is likely Arsenal's hardest remaining fixture. After all, Liverpool - until recently the other title contender - saw its season turned upside down after a loss at United in the FA Cup quarterfinals on March 17 was followed by a costly draw at Old Trafford in the league on April 7.\n\nThe Premier League is the only one of Europe's top five leagues where the title race is still bubbling. Germany's Bundesliga (champions Bayer Leverkusen), Italy's Serie A (Inter Milan) and France's Ligue 1 (Paris Saint-Germain) have been decided, while Real Madrid leads Barcelona by 11 points in Spain's La Liga.\n\nEUROPEAN PLACES\n\nArsenal, City and Liverpool are locks for Champions League qualification, with fourth-place Aston Villa likely to join them. Tottenham is isolated in fifth, the reward for which is Europa League qualification.\n\nThe remaining intrigue, then, revolves around which teams finishes in sixth and seventh to likely earn a berth in the Europa Conference League. Manchester United, Newcastle and Chelsea are the teams occupying sixth to eighth places and three points separate them with four games left for each. West Ham and Bournemouth have outside shots in ninth and 10th, respectively.\n\nChelsea is in the best form, having lost just one of its last 11 games - though that was 5-0 at Arsenal.\n\nIf United drops to eighth, the team has a last chance to get into Europe by winning the FA Cup final against Man City a week after the Premier League finishes.\n\nThe relegation battle looks like it will go to the final day of the season - and won't just be determined by what happens on the field. With last-place Sheffield United already down, there are three teams fighting to avoid the two remaining relegation places: Nottingham Forest (26 points), Luton (25 points) and Burnley (24 points).\n\nEach team has three games left and, significantly, two of them meet in the final round when Burnley hosts Forest.\n\nForest's current points total is subject to change, however, because the club has appealed against a four-point deduction for breaching the league's financial rules. The result of that appeal should be known before the end of the season, meaning Forest could recover some points based on the views of an independent panel.\n\nIf Burnley and Luton are also relegated, it means the three teams that came up last year lasted just one season before going back down to the Championship.\n\nPromotion\n\nThere's one automatic promotion spot up for grabs heading into the final round of games in the second-tier Championship on Saturday.\n\nLeicester has already clinched promotion and an immediate return to the Premier League. The team will go up as champions.\n\nIpswich or Leeds will join them. Ipswich, which last played in the top flight in 2002, is currently in second place and three points ahead of third-place Leeds, whose American ownership group includes major-winning golfers Jordan Spieth and Justin Thomas.\n\nIpswich hosts next-to-last Huddersfield, and Leeds is at home to fourth-place Southampton. The teams placed third to sixth will compete in the playoffs for the third promotion spot. {"uri": "8111456606", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "18:43:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T18:43:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T18:40:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/sports/haaland-scores-4-in-another-win-for-man-city-arsenal-isnt-going-away-in-the/article_ea0fdcdc-f79c-5e92-a732-bb45a0d479d8.html", "title": "Haaland scores 4 in another win for Man City. Arsenal isn't going away in the title race, though", "body": "Manchester City's Erling Haaland, right, scores his side's fourth goal during the English Premier League soccer match between Manchester City and Wolverhampton Wanderers at the Etihad Stadium in Manchester, England, Saturday, May 4, 2024.\n\nFour goals for Erling Haaland. Another win for Manchester City in its bid to capture an unprecedented fourth straight Premier League crown.\n\nArsenal, though, isn't going away in the title race.\n\nNot this time.\n\nHaaland has now at least a hat trick in six of his 63 matches in England's top flight after converting two penalties, powering in a header and curling home a sublime finish in City's 5-1 victory over Wolverhampton on Saturday. Julian Alvarez added a late fifth, moments after coming on as a substitute for Haaland.\n\nThat's six straight wins for the defending champions in their five-month unbeaten streak in the league. Three more wins -- away to Fulham and Tottenham and then at home to West Ham -- and the title is theirs once again.\n\nCity might need to be perfect down the stretch to hold off Arsenal.\n\nThere's no sign of an end-of-season collapse by Mikel Arteta's team this time, with a 3-0 win over Bournemouth in the lunchtime kickoff keeping the pressure on City.\n\nArsenal has four straight wins itself and has retained its one-point lead. City, though, has three games left, one more than Arsenal.\n\nLast season, Arsenal's title challenge faded in the spring as a fast-finishing City clinched a third straight league championship with three games to spare.\n\nTwelve months on and the title race is heading into the final week of the season. Indeed, given the form of the top two, it is likely to be decided in the last round of games on May 19.\n\nBukayo Saka converted a penalty in the 45th minute before second-half goals by Leandro Trossard and Declan Rice gave Arsenal victory at Emirates Stadium.\n\nBURNLEY IN TROUBLE\n\nBurnley slipped closer to the drop thanks to its 4-1 loss at home to Newcastle combined with relegation rival Nottingham Forest's 3-1 win at last-place Sheffield United.\n\nIt left next-to-last Burnley five points adrift of Forest, which occupies the place directly above the relegation zone.\n\nBurnley has to win both of its remaining games -- away to Tottenham and then at home to Forest on the final day -- to stand a chance of staying up. Even that won't be enough if Forest avoids defeat at West Ham next weekend, given Burnley's goal difference is so much worse than Forest's.\n\nLuton, which drew 1-1 with Everton on Friday, is third from bottom and now three points behind Forest. As it stands, the three teams that were promoted last season are going straight back down to the Championship.\n\nCallum Wilson, Sean Longstaff, Bruno Guimaraes and Alexander Isak all scored for Newcastle, which climbed above Manchester United and into sixth place in its bid to qualify for Europe. Newcastle could even catch Tottenham, which is four points further ahead in fifth ahead of its trip to Liverpool on Sunday.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nMan United visits Crystal Palace on Monday.\n\nSheffield United was already sure of being relegated before playing Forest, which came from behind through a double from Callum Hudson-Odoi that came either side of Ryan Yates' goal.\n\nIn the other match Saturday, Brentford and Fulham drew 0-0.\n\nTOP SCORER RACE\n\nHaaland's four goals have left him in sight of the Golden Boot -- awarded to the league's top scorer -- for the second straight season.\n\nThe Norway striker has 25 for the campaign, five more than Isak and Chelsea's Cole Palmer. Ollie Watkins of Aston Villa is one goal further back.\n\nHaaland scored 36 goals in the league last season.\n\nIPSWICH PROMOTED\n\nThere will be a refreshing name in the Premier League next season.\n\nIpswich sealed a return to England's top division for the first time in 22 years after finishing as runner-up on the last day of the second-tier Championship's regular season.\n\nA 2-0 win over Huddersfield saw Ipswich beat Leeds to the second automatic qualification spot, behind Leicester.\n\nLeeds joined Southampton, West Bromwich Albion and Norwich in the playoffs for the third promotion spot. Leeds will play Norwich over two legs and Southampton takes on West Brom.\n\nThe playoff final is at Wembley Stadium on May 26.\n\nSteve Douglas is at https://twitter.com/sdouglas80\n\nAP soccer: {"uri": "8111799675", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "03:07:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T03:07:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T03:07:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/manchester-united-could-hand-man-29115190", "title": "Man United could hand Man City a huge Premier League title advantage", "body": "Manchester City are a point behind Arsenal at the top of the Premier League table with a game in hand\n\nManchester City could be crowned Premier League champions with a game to spare having eased past Wolves on Saturday.\n\nErling Haaland struck a first half hat-trick at the Etihad Stadium, including two penalties, to put the result beyond doubt before the break. He added a fourth seconds after Hwang Hee-chan had scored for Wolves and sub Julian Alvarez put the gloss on a 5-1 win to move City within a point of leaders Arsenal with a game in hand.\n\nIndeed City could be celebrating the title before the final weekend of the season if rivals Manchester United do them a favour. Arsenal are on 83 points following their victory over Bournemouth. Mikel Arteta's side have two games to play - at Manchester United and at home to Everton. It means they can reach a maximum of 89.\n\nALSO READ: Man City player ratings vs Wolves as Erling Haaland and Rodri class\n\nALSO READ: What Haaland did before and after fourth City goal should worry Arsenal\n\nCity will be unable to win the title next weekend following Arsenal's most recent success, even if they see off Fulham at Craven Cottage on Saturday lunchtime and the Gunners lose at Old Trafford on the Sunday.\n\nBut, if Arsenal fail to beat United and City defeat Fulham and then Spurs the following Tuesday, then Guardiola's men would be crowned champions in the capital. Any other combination of results would see the title race go to the final day of the season when City take on West Ham and Arsenal face Everton.\n\nCity are seeking an unprecedented fourth straight Premier League title while Arsenal haven't been crowned champions since their unbeaten season of 2004. {"uri": "8111594672", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "21:39:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T21:39:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T21:34:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://japantoday.com/category/sports/arsenal-is-taking-the-premier-league-title-race-to-the-wire-after-extending-winning-streak", "title": "Haaland scores 4 in another win for Man City; Arsenal isn't going away in title race, though", "body": "Four goals for Erling Haaland. Another win for Manchester City in its bid to capture an unprecedented fourth straight Premier League crown.\n\nArsenal, though, isn't going away in the title race.\n\nNot this time.\n\nHaaland has now at least a hat trick in six of his 63 matches in England's top flight after converting two penalties either side of a towering header and curling home a sublime finish in City's 5-1 victory over Wolverhampton on Saturday. Julian Alvarez added a late fifth, moments after coming on as a substitute for Haaland.\n\n\"Erling is back to business,\" City manager Pep Guardiola said. \"Penalties are a guarantee but the second and fourth (goals) were unbelievable.\"\n\nThat's six straight wins for the defending champions in their five-month unbeaten streak in the league. Three more wins -- away to Fulham and Tottenham and then at home to West Ham -- and the title is theirs once again.\n\nCity might need to be perfect down the stretch to hold off Arsenal.\n\nThere's no sign of an end-of-season collapse by Mikel Arteta's team this time, with a 3-0 win over Bournemouth in the lunchtime kickoff keeping the pressure on City.\n\nArsenal has four straight wins itself and has retained its one-point lead. City, though, has three games left, one more than Arsenal.\n\nLast season, Arsenal's title challenge faded in the spring as a fast-finishing City clinched a third straight league championship with three games to spare.\n\nTwelve months on and the title race is heading into the final week of the season. Indeed, given the form of the top two, it is likely to be decided in the last round of games on May 19.\n\nBukayo Saka converted a penalty in the 45th minute before second-half goals by Leandro Trossard and Declan Rice gave Arsenal victory at Emirates Stadium.\n\nBURNLEY IN TROUBLE\n\nBurnley slipped closer to the drop thanks to its 4-1 loss at home to Newcastle combined with relegation rival Nottingham Forest's 3-1 win at last-place Sheffield United.\n\nIt left next-to-last Burnley five points adrift of Forest, which occupies the place directly above the relegation zone.\n\nBurnley has to win both of its remaining games -- away to Tottenham and then at home to Forest on the final day -- to stand a chance of staying up. Even that won't be enough if Forest avoids defeat at West Ham next weekend, given Burnley's goal difference is so much worse than Forest's.\n\nLuton, which drew 1-1 with Everton on Friday, is third from bottom and now three points behind Forest. As it stands, the three teams that were promoted last season are going straight back down to the Championship.\n\nCallum Wilson, Sean Longstaff, Bruno Guimaraes and Alexander Isak all scored for Newcastle, which climbed above Manchester United and into sixth place in its bid to qualify for Europe. Newcastle could even catch Tottenham, which is four points further ahead in fifth ahead of its trip to Liverpool on Sunday.\n\nMan United visits Crystal Palace on Monday.\n\nSheffield United was already sure of being relegated before playing Forest, which came from behind through a double from Callum Hudson-Odoi that came either side of Ryan Yates' goal.\n\nIn the other match Saturday, Brentford and Fulham drew 0-0.\n\nTOP SCORER RACE\n\nHaaland's four goals have left him in sight of the Golden Boot -- awarded to the league's top scorer -- for the second straight season.\n\nThe Norway striker has 25 for the campaign, five more than Isak and Chelsea's Cole Palmer. Ollie Watkins of Aston Villa is one goal further back.\n\nHaaland scored 36 goals in the league last season.\n\nIPSWICH PROMOTED\n\nThere will be a refreshing name in the Premier League next season.\n\nIpswich sealed a return to England's top division for the first time in 22 years after finishing as runner-up on the last day of the second-tier Championship's regular season.\n\nA 2-0 win over Huddersfield saw Ipswich beat Leeds to the second automatic qualification spot, behind Leicester.\n\nLeeds joined Southampton, West Bromwich Albion and Norwich in the playoffs for the third promotion spot. Leeds will play Norwich over two legs and Southampton takes on West Brom.\n\nThe playoff final is at Wembley Stadium on May 26.\n\n\u00a9 Copyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-05-344161077", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "15:43:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T15:43:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T05:16:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.cbs17.com/sports/ap-title-relegation-and-european-spots-in-the-balance-as-premier-league-heads-for-exciting-finale/", "title": "Title, relegation and European spots in the balance as Premier League heads for exciting finale", "body": "And the contest for the remaining European qualification positions contains as many as five.\n\nThe Premier League season is down to its last two weeks and there's still plenty at stake from top to bottom.\n\nMeanwhile, the second-tier Championship's regular season finishes on Saturday, with a second automatic promotion spot set to be secured.\n\nThis time, Arsenal vs. Manchester City for the Premier League title looks like going down to the wire.\n\nCity took advantage of a late-season collapse by the Gunners to win the league with three matches to spare in the 2022-23 campaign, but an improved Arsenal might last the course this time round.\n\nArsenal leads by one point with three games to go -- against Bournemouth at home on Saturday, Manchester United away and Everton at home. City has four games remaining -- at home to Wolverhampton, away to Fulham and Tottenham, and at home to West Ham -- and would capture an unprecedented fourth straight title by winning all of them.\n\nThe pressure is on the defending champions to do that because even just one draw could be fatal. Arsenal has a superior goal difference and, as it stands, would win on that tiebreaker if the teams are equal on points.\n\nAway to Tottenham looks to be the toughest match for City, which has yet to win -- or even score -- in four league games at Tottenham's new stadium that opened in 2019. Spurs fans will have mixed feelings about the May 14 game, because a win for their team could hand Arsenal, Tottenham's fierce north London rival, the title.\n\nA trip to Old Trafford is likely Arsenal's hardest remaining fixture. After all, Liverpool -- until recently the other title contender -- saw its season turned upside down after a loss at United in the FA Cup quarterfinals on March 17 was followed by a costly draw at Old Trafford in the league on April 7.\n\nThe Premier League is the only one of Europe's top five leagues where the title race is still bubbling. Germany's Bundesliga (champions Bayer Leverkusen), Italy's Serie A (Inter Milan) and France's Ligue 1 (Paris Saint-Germain) have been decided, while Real Madrid leads Barcelona by 11 points in Spain's La Liga.\n\nEUROPEAN PLACES\n\nArsenal, City and Liverpool are locks for Champions League qualification, with fourth-place Aston Villa likely to join them. Tottenham is isolated in fifth, the reward for which is Europa League qualification.\n\nThe remaining intrigue, then, revolves around which teams finishes in sixth and seventh to likely earn a berth in the Europa Conference League. Manchester United, Newcastle and Chelsea are the teams occupying sixth to eighth places and three points separate them with four games left for each. West Ham and Bournemouth have outside shots in ninth and 10th, respectively.\n\nChelsea is in the best form, having lost just one of its last 11 games -- though that was 5-0 at Arsenal.\n\nIf United drops to eighth, the team has a last chance to get into Europe by winning the FA Cup final against Man City a week after the Premier League finishes.\n\nRELEGATION\n\nThe relegation battle looks like it will go to the final day of the season -- and won't just be determined by what happens on the field.\n\nWith last-place Sheffield United already down, there are three teams fighting to avoid the two remaining relegation places: Nottingham Forest (26 points), Luton (25 points) and Burnley (24 points).\n\nEach team has three games left and, significantly, two of them meet in the final round when Burnley hosts Forest.\n\nForest's current points total is subject to change, however, because the club has appealed against a four-point deduction for breaching the league's financial rules. The result of that appeal should be known before the end of the season, meaning Forest could recover some points based on the views of an independent panel.\n\nIf Burnley and Luton are also relegated, it means the three teams that came up last year lasted just one season before going back down to the Championship.\n\nPROMOTION\n\nThere's one automatic promotion spot up for grabs heading into the final round of games in the second-tier Championship on Saturday.\n\nLeicester has already clinched promotion and an immediate return to the Premier League. The team will go up as champions.\n\nIpswich or Leeds will join them.\n\nIpswich, which last played in the top flight in 2002, is currently in second place and three points ahead of third-place Leeds, whose American ownership group includes major-winning golfers Jordan Spieth and Justin Thomas.\n\nIpswich hosts next-to-last Huddersfield, and Leeds is at home to fourth-place Southampton.\n\nThe teams placed third to sixth will compete in the playoffs for the third promotion spot. The playoff final is at Wembley Stadium on May 26.", "source": {"uri": "cbs17.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS17.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@cbs17.com", "name": "Associated Nottingham Forest moved three points clear of the bottom three with a 3-1 win at Sheffield United, and Brentford and Fulham played a scoreless draw.\n\nHours before City's ruthless victory, Arsenal cleared another hurdle in their hunt for their first league title in 20 years.\n\nA penalty shortly before halftime converted by Bukayo Saka gave Arsenal the lead. Leandro Trossard eased the nerves inside the Emirates with a second goal on 70 minutes and Declan Rice added the third deep into stoppage time.\n\n\"We played probably the best first half we've played all season. We could have gone three, four, five easily. We scored one,\" Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta said.\n\n\"Then credit to Bournemouth they changed things and the game became more open which we wanted to avoid.\"\n\nArsenal next travel to Old Trafford to play Manchester United before hosting Everton on the final day.\n\nIf City felt pressure from Arsenal's win, it did not show as Haaland and the holders ran roughshod over Wolves at the Etihad.\n\n\"Nine (more) points, we will be champions. Seven points, six points, three points, Arsenal will win the Premier League,\" Guardiola said.\n\nHaaland -- who boosted his league scoring lead to 25 with the first four-goal haul of his career -- scored from the penalty spot in the 12th minute, then doubled City's lead in the 35th when he headed home at the far post from Rodri's cross.\n\nThe 23-year-old converted again from the spot just before halftime. Hwang Hee-chan pulled one back for Wolves in the 53rd but Haaland scored his fourth a minute later. Substitute Julian Alvarez completed City's scoring.\n\nGuardiola's team play away at Fulham and Tottenham Hotspur before closing the season at home to West Ham United.\n\nAlexander Isak scored his 20th league goal of the season to lead Newcastle in their romp over Burnley, keeping alive their hopes of playing European football next season.\n\nCallum Wilson, Sean Longstaff and Bruno Guimaraes also got on the scoresheet on a day soured only slightly by Isak's missed penalty.\n\n\"When we're really aggressive and running forward we are a really good team. It's been there in fits and starts this season, but a really good day and something to build on,\" Longstaff told the BBC.\n\nBurnley could have their relegation confirmed when they travel to Spurs next Saturday.\n\nBIG STEP FOR FOREST\n\nA brace by Callum Hudson-Odoi helped Forest breathe a little easier as they climbed three points above the drop zone, gaining a crucial lead over 18th-placed Luton Town with two games to go for both teams.\n\nSheffield, already relegated, remained bottom with 16 points.\n\n\"It was a big step for us but it's not over yet,\" Forest manager Nuno Espirito Santo said. \"We've still got hard games to play.\"\n\nSheffield took the lead in the 16th minute on a penalty from Ben Brereton Diaz, but the visitors equalised 11 minutes later when Danilo found Hudson-Odoi in the box.\n\nRyan Yates gave Forest the lead with his first ever league goal shortly after the break before Hudson-Odoi fired into the near bottom corner to complete his brace in the 65th minute.\n\nSheffield became the first club to concede 100 goals in a 38-match Premier League season. Swindon Town, who also conceded 100 goals in 1993-94, did so over 42 games.\n\nFulham substitute Raul Jimenez missed a golden chance to settle the West London derby against Brentford in a game of missed chances.\n\nJimenez had been on the field for nine minutes when set up by Adama Traore's cross but, despite having time and space, he sent his 73rd-minute effort sailing over the crossbar.\n\nFulham are 12th in the table, while Brentford are 16th. The Gunners have played with more vigor and maturity this season, claiming 83 points from 36 games so far. They are currently sitting at the top of the Premier League rankings, a point ahead of second-placed Manchester City.\n\nUnfortunately for the Gunners, however, the Cityzens have a game in hand, meaning the defending champions will retain their title if they win their remaining three matches.\n\nThanks to their experience in this stage of the competition, Manchester City are favorites to clinch their fourth Premier League title on the bounce this season. Guardiola, however, is refusing to be complacent and has urged all of his players to give their all to deny the Gunners their first Premier League title since 2003-04.\n\nSpeaking to the press after dispatching Wolverhampton Wanderers on Saturday (May 4), Guardiola emphasized how important it was for his team to win the next three games. He claimed Arsenal were in majestic form and would not drop points in their last two games of the season.\n\nThe Spanish tactician remarked (via Football.London):\n\n\"If we win the games we will be champions, so the players know it, feel it, and have the experience of doing it in the past. But they have to do it again. It's going to be easy? No. It's in our hands but everyone knows you cannot make one little mistake because you will lose the Premier League. They know it, we know it.\n\n\"You see their [Arsenal's] level of consistency since the winter break, the way they are playing. It's not the fact that they are winning, it's the way they play. You smell that they are not going to lose in the games they have left. They are not going to.\"\n\nArsenal will face Manchester United (Away, May 12) and Everton (Home, May 19) in their last two games of the season. {"uri": "8111618688", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "22:08:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T22:08:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T22:07:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.newshub.co.nz/home/sport/2024/05/english-premier-league-arsenal-manchester-city-both-win-to-continue-neck-and-neck-title-race.html", "title": "English Premier League: Arsenal, Manchester City both win to continue neck-and-neck title race | Newshub", "body": "Arsenal goal highlights. Credits: Image - Getty Images; Video - Sky Sport\n\nManchester City remained on course for a fourth successive Premier League title with a ruthless 5-1 win over Wolverhampton Wanderers on Sunday (NZ time), hours after Arsenal's 3-0 win over Bournemouth kept them provisionally top of the standings.\n\nErling Haaland struck four times as Pep Guardiola's team pulled to within a point of Arsenal with a game in hand.\n\nNewcastle United moved into sixth place with a 4-1 victory at Burnley that left the hosts on the brink of relegation. Nottingham Forest moved three points clear of the bottom three with a 3-1 win at Sheffield United, and Brentford and Fulham played a scoreless draw.\n\nHours before City's ruthless victory, Arsenal cleared another hurdle in their hunt for their first league title in 20 years.\n\nA penalty shortly before halftime converted by Bukayo Saka gave Arsenal the lead. Leandro Trossard eased the nerves inside the Emirates with a second goal on 70 minutes and Declan Rice added the third deep into stoppage time.\n\n\"We played probably the best first half we've played all season. We could have gone three, four, five easily. We scored one,\" Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta said.\n\n\"Then credit to Bournemouth they changed things and the game became more open which we wanted to avoid.\"\n\nArsenal next travel to Old Trafford to play Manchester United before hosting Everton on the final day.\n\nIf City felt pressure from Arsenal's win, it did not show as Haaland and the holders ran roughshod over Wolves at the Etihad.\n\n\"Nine (more) points, we will be champions. Seven points, six points, three points, Arsenal will win the Premier League,\" Guardiola said.\n\nHaaland -- who boosted his league scoring lead to 25 with the first four-goal haul of his career -- scored from the penalty spot in the 12th minute, then doubled City's lead in the 35th when he headed home at the far post from Rodri's cross.\n\nThe 23-year-old converted again from the spot just before halftime. Hwang Hee-chan pulled one back for Wolves in the 53rd but Haaland scored his fourth a minute later. Substitute Julian Alvarez completed City's scoring.\n\nGuardiola's team play away at Fulham and Tottenham Hotspur before closing the season at home to West Ham United.\n\nAlexander Isak scored his 20th league goal of the season to lead Newcastle in their romp over Burnley, keeping alive their hopes of playing European football next season.\n\nCallum Wilson, Sean Longstaff and Bruno Guimaraes also got on the scoresheet on a day soured only slightly by Isak's missed penalty.\n\n\"When we're really aggressive and running forward we are a really good team. It's been there in fits and starts this season, but a really good day and something to build on,\" Longstaff told the BBC.\n\nBurnley could have their relegation confirmed when they travel to Spurs next Saturday.\n\nA brace by Callum Hudson-Odoi helped Forest breathe a little easier as they climbed three points above the drop zone, gaining a crucial lead over 18th-placed Luton Town with two games to go for both teams.\n\nSheffield, already relegated, remained bottom with 16 points.\n\n\"It was a big step for us but it's not over yet,\" Forest manager Nuno Espirito Santo said. \"We've still got hard games to play.\"\n\nSheffield took the lead in the 16th minute on a penalty from Ben Brereton Diaz, but the visitors equalised 11 minutes later when Danilo found Hudson-Odoi in the box.\n\nRyan Yates gave Forest the lead with his first ever league goal shortly after the break before Hudson-Odoi fired into the near bottom corner to complete his brace in the 65th minute.\n\nSheffield became the first club to concede 100 goals in a 38-match Premier League season. Swindon Town, who also conceded 100 goals in 1993-94, did so over 42 games.\n\nFulham substitute Raul Jimenez missed a golden chance to settle the West London derby against Brentford in a game of missed chances.\n\nJimenez had been on the field for nine minutes when set up by Adama Traore's cross but, despite having time and space, he sent his 73rd-minute effort sailing over the crossbar.\n\nFulham are 12th in the table, while Brentford are 16th. Both teams have two matches remaining.\n\nReuters.", "source": {"uri": "newshub.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "Newshub"}, "authors": [{"uri": "reuters@newshub.co.nz", "name": "Reuters", "type":
