{"uri": "8111844071", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "04:11:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T04:11:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T04:10:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2024-05-05/football/Haaland-scores-4-in-another-win-for-Man-City-Arsenal-not-going-away-in-the-title-race-though-6736260815", "title": "Haaland scores 4 in another win for Man City; Arsenal not going away in the title race, though - The Malta Independent", "body": "Four goals for Erling Haaland. Another win for Manchester City in its bid to capture an unprecedented fourth straight Premier League crown.\n\nHaaland has now at least a hat trick in six of his 63 matches in England's top flight after converting two penalties either side of a towering header and curling home a sublime finish in City's 5-1 victory over Wolverhampton on Saturday. Julian Alvarez added a late fifth, moments after coming on as a substitute for Haaland.\n\n\"Erling is back to business,\" City manager Pep Guardiola said. \"Penalties are a guarantee but the second and fourth (goals) were unbelievable.\"\n\nThat's six straight wins for the defending champions in their five-month unbeaten streak in the league. Three more wins -- away to Fulham and Tottenham and then at home to West Ham -- and the title is theirs once again.\n\nCity might need to be perfect down the stretch to hold off Arsenal.\n\nThere's no sign of an end-of-season collapse by Mikel Arteta's team this time, with a 3-0 win over Bournemouth in the lunchtime kickoff keeping the pressure on City.\n\nArsenal has four straight wins itself and has retained its one-point lead. City, though, has three games left, one more than Arsenal.\n\nLast season, Arsenal's title challenge faded in the spring as a fast-finishing City clinched a third straight league championship with three games to spare.\n\nTwelve months on and the title race is heading into the final week of the season. Indeed, given the form of the top two, it is likely to be decided in the last round of games on May 19.\n\nBukayo Saka converted a penalty in the 45th minute before second-half goals by Leandro Trossard and Declan Rice gave Arsenal victory at Emirates Stadium.\n\nBURNLEY IN TROUBLE\n\nBurnley slipped closer to the drop thanks to its 4-1 loss at home to Newcastle combined with relegation rival Nottingham Forest's 3-1 win at last-place Sheffield United.\n\nIt left next-to-last Burnley five points adrift of Forest, which occupies the place directly above the relegation zone.\n\nBurnley has to win both of its remaining games -- away to Tottenham and then at home to Forest on the final day -- to stand a chance of staying up. Even that won't be enough if Forest avoids defeat at West Ham next weekend, given Burnley's goal difference is so much worse than Forest's.\n\nLuton, which drew 1-1 with Everton on Friday, is third from bottom and now three points behind Forest. As it stands, the three teams that were promoted last season are going straight back down to the Championship.\n\nCallum Wilson, Sean Longstaff, Bruno Guimaraes and Alexander Isak all scored for Newcastle, which climbed above Manchester United and into sixth place in its bid to qualify for Europe. Newcastle could even catch Tottenham, which is four points further ahead in fifth ahead of its trip to Liverpool on Sunday.\n\nMan United visits Crystal Palace on Monday.\n\nSheffield United was already sure of being relegated before playing Forest, which came from behind through a double from Callum Hudson-Odoi that came either side of Ryan Yates' goal.\n\nIn the other match Saturday, Brentford and Fulham drew 0-0.\n\nTOP SCORER RACE\n\nHaaland's four goals have left him in sight of the Golden Boot -- awarded to the league's top scorer -- for the second straight season.\n\nThe Norway striker has 25 for the campaign, five more than Isak and Chelsea's Cole Palmer. However, unsurprisingly, it wasn't to be and Manchester City scored five, closing the points gap again and the goal difference by one.\n\nThis has led to many suddenly panicking that the advantage in goals that Arsenal have has come into question with the two and three games each respective side has remaining in this Premier League season. City face Fulham (A) Tottenham (A) and West Ham (H) whilst Arsenal travel to Old Trafford before hosting Everton on the final day.\n\nAt present the goal difference is split by just six, which feels close when considering the capabilities of Man City to narrow that gap with an extra game, and looks far more realistic than the calm tone this article's intro might suggest. That said, goal difference will only be relevant should Man City draw one of their three games with them winning the other two, and Arsenal winning their final games also.\n\nTherefore it can be assumed for the goal difference to matter, both City and Arsenal have two games remaining in this context. Should Arsenal win both their remaining games, at the very minimum it will be achieved by a one-goal difference taking their gap over Manchester City to eight.\n\nTherefore, should City draw one of their three games and Arsenal win both of theirs by a maximum margin of one in each, City would need to score by a winning margin of nine goals in the other two clashes. Whilst sounding somewhat complicated the likelihood will be that Arsenal will win against Manchester United and Everton by more than just a one-goal margin meaning that City will need win by a combined double-figure margin to win the league on goal difference.\n\nIn short, fans need not worry too greatly about the goal difference with the chances of it winning City the league very slim. The reality is Arsenal will not only need to beat both Man United and Everton but need something of a miracle to fall in their favour in City's remaining three games.\n\nSuggestions that Arsenal will have 'crumbled' or 'bottled it' should be held back too. The Gunners are currently topping the league table with 83 points in 36 games, a point above second-placed Manchester City who have a game in hand.\n\nLast weekend, Arsenal maintained their push for the league title by beating Bournemouth 3-0. Hours later, Manchester City kept up with Gunners' pace by smashing Wolves 5-1.\n\nInterestingly, this coming weekend, Manchester City have an away game against Fulham on Saturday, May 11, which coach Pep Guardiola and his boys are likely to win.\n\nOn Sunday, May 12, Arsenal will travel to Old Trafford to take on Manchester United, a game Gary Neville believes could make a lot of difference in the title race.\n\nAccording to Neville, if Arsenal lose or draw against Manchester United on Sunday after City's victory over Fulham on Saturday, and Guardiola's team beat Tottenham Hotspur on Tuesday, May 14, City will be crowned champions of the league before the last matchday of the season.\n\n\"It (the title race) may go down to the final day, and if it went to the final day, that would mean Arsenal have gone and beaten Manchester United at Old Trafford\", Gary Neville said while speaking on his podcast.\n\n\"While we can laugh and we can giggle about how Manchester United have been, but Arsenal going to Old Trafford and winning, that's going to be a hell of a win.\n\n\"So, yeah, I have the fear that the title could be over in a week on Tuesday when in terms of sort of the neutrals, I Arsenal isn't going away in the title race, though", "body": "Four goals for Erling Haaland. Another win for Manchester City in its bid to capture an unprecedented fourth straight Premier League crown.\n\nArsenal, though, isn't going away in the title race.\n\nNot this time.\n\nHaaland has now at least a hat trick in six of his 63 matches in England's top flight after converting two penalties, powering in a header and curling home a sublime finish in City's 5-1 victory over Wolverhampton on Saturday. Julian Alvarez added a late fifth, moments after coming on as a substitute for Haaland.\n\nThat's six straight wins for the defending champions in their five-month unbeaten streak in the league. Three more wins -- away to Fulham and Tottenham and then at home to West Ham -- and the title is theirs once again.\n\nCity might need to be perfect down the stretch to hold off Arsenal.\n\nThere's no sign of an end-of-season collapse by Mikel Arteta's team this time, with a 3-0 win over Bournemouth in the lunchtime kickoff keeping the pressure on City.\n\nArsenal has four straight wins itself and has retained its one-point lead. City, though, has three games left, one more than Arsenal.\n\nLast season, Arsenal's title challenge faded in the spring as a fast-finishing City clinched a third straight league championship with three games to spare.\n\nTwelve months on and the title race is heading into the final week of the season. Indeed, given the form of the top two, it is likely to be decided in the last round of games on May 19.\n\nBukayo Saka converted a penalty in the 45th minute before second-half goals by Leandro Trossard and Declan Rice gave Arsenal victory at Emirates Stadium.\n\nBURNLEY IN TROUBLE\n\nBurnley slipped closer to the drop thanks to its 4-1 loss at home to Newcastle combined with relegation rival Nottingham Forest's 3-1 win at last-place Sheffield United.\n\nIt left next-to-last Burnley five points adrift of Forest, which occupies the place directly above the relegation zone.\n\nBurnley has to win both of its remaining games -- away to Tottenham and then at home to Forest on the final day -- to stand a chance of staying up. Even that won't be enough if Forest avoids defeat at West Ham next weekend, given Burnley's goal difference is so much worse than Forest's.\n\nLuton, which drew 1-1 with Everton on Friday, is third from bottom and now three points behind Forest. As it stands, the three teams that were promoted last season are going straight back down to the Championship.\n\nCallum Wilson, Sean Longstaff, Bruno Guimaraes and Alexander Isak all scored for Newcastle, which climbed above Manchester United and into sixth place in its bid to qualify for Europe. Newcastle could even catch Tottenham, which is four points further ahead in fifth ahead of its trip to Liverpool on Sunday.\n\nMan United visits Crystal Palace on Monday.\n\nSheffield United was already sure of being relegated before playing Forest, which came from behind through a double from Callum Hudson-Odoi that came either side of Ryan Yates' goal.\n\nIn the other match Saturday, Brentford and Fulham drew 0-0.\n\nTOP SCORER RACE\n\nHaaland's four goals have left him in sight of the Golden Boot -- awarded to the league's top scorer -- for the second straight season.\n\nThe Norway striker has 25 for the campaign, five more than Isak and Chelsea's Cole Palmer. Ollie Watkins of Aston Villa is one goal further back.\n\nHaaland scored 36 goals in the league last season.\n\nIPSWICH PROMOTED\n\nThere will be a refreshing name in the Premier League next season.\n\nIpswich sealed a return to England's top division for the first time in 22 years after finishing as runner-up on the last day of the second-tier Championship's regular season.\n\nA 2-0 win over Huddersfield saw Ipswich beat Leeds to the second automatic qualification spot, behind Leicester.\n\nLeeds joined Southampton, West Bromwich Albion and Norwich in the playoffs for the third promotion spot. {"uri": "2024-05-345705609", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "15:09:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T15:09:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T15:08:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.modernghana.com/sports/1310178/arsenal-left-praying-while-man-city-shine-as.html", "title": "'Arsenal left praying while Man City shine as end game nears'", "body": "GETTY IMAGES Image caption: Erling Haaland has now scored seven goals in his past four Premier League games\n\nWe are nearing the end game now.\n\nAs Manchester City boss Pep Guardiola rather succinctly put it: \"One week left, three games left. Nine points and we will be champions. Seven, six or three points, Arsenal will win the Premier League.\"\n\nGuardiola is not placing much faith in Manchester United then, given he expects Arsenal to win every game and the Gunners visit Old Trafford on 12 May.\n\nBut, then, he doesn't have to.\n\nIf City win their final three games they will go into the history books as the first team to win the English title in four successive seasons.\n\nFour Erling Haaland goals against Wolves ensured City navigated their latest obstacle with ease. Now it is on to Craven Cottage and Fulham, a team they have beaten 15 times in a row.\n\nThey finish with West Ham at home. City have not dropped a point at Etihad Stadium against the Hammers since Guardiola arrived in 2016.\n\nIn between comes a trip to Tottenham. City have not scored a Premier League goal or taken a point at Spurs' new stadium. They did win there in the FA Cup this season, though, and Ange Postecoglou's team are in terrible form.\n\nAnd, as Wolves boss Gary O'Neil pointed out, this is the hardest time to play City.\n\n\"Manchester City, in May, when they are chasing down a fourth consecutive Premier League title, are fairly tough,\" he said.\n\n\"They have an incredible focus at this point. History tells you, at this point in the run-in, they are difficult to stop.\"\n\nThe one negative for City is that Arsenal's goal difference is better by six, which means they have to win to reach the top. A draw will not do.\n\n\"Goal difference is not possible,\" Guardiola said. \"We cannot draw. We have to take nine points.\"\n\nIn a separate interview with BBC Match of the Day, he added: \"Hopefully, we can come back here in a few days and have the chance against West Ham to come here and win the title.\"\n\nFor City to get to the West Ham game and not have a chance of the title, it would require Arsenal to beat Manchester United and for City to get no more than a point from the Fulham and Tottenham trips.\n\nThat feels unlikely for a team that has put an astonishing run together of 16 wins and four draws since they were beaten at Aston Villa on 6 December.\n\nNot that it should come as a surprise.\n\nLast season, City went on a 16-match unbeaten run, winning 14 times, to take the title before they lost at Brentford on the final day. The year before that, they won 23 times in a run of one defeat in 28. The season before that, they won 17 times in a 19-match unbeaten sequence.\n\n\"When you are coming towards the end of the season, you do think differently,\" former City defender Micah Richards told Sky Sports. \"These games are the most important and that's where City seem to thrive.\"\n\nAs Richards' fellow pundit Jamie Redknapp said, Arsenal's task is straightforward.\n\nThey must win at Old Trafford and then again against Everton on the final day. Anything else is completely out of their hands.\n\nGiven the run Mikel Arteta's side have been on, and the two seasons they have had, few would begrudge the Gunners a first title since 2004.\n\nBut, as Jurgen Klopp and Liverpool have found out, running City close and overhauling them are two different matters.\n\n\"They are an unbelievable team,\" said Arsenal midfielder Declan Rice. \"What I have learned in this title race is that you have to be nearly perfect. They have done that for three years in a row.\n\n\"I have massive respect for what they have done. But we have two games to go and we're praying for something to go our way.\"", "source": {"uri": "modernghana.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Modern Ghana Media Communication Ltd."}, "authors": The former United defender predicts that the Gunners will drop points at Old Trafford on Sunday (May 12), and City will defeat the Spurs to secure their fourth consecutive title.\n\n\"I have that fear the title race could be over a week on Tuesday. I want the title race to go to the final day, my fear is it won't if City win on Saturday against Fulham and United take points off Arsenal on the Sunday. Arsenal have already proven they are a different side than last season but just feels like an inevitability City will be perfect until the end,'\" Neville said.\n\nManchester City are 82 points strong in the second position in the league table, one point behind table leaders Arsenal. However, Pep Guardiola's side has a game in hand than the Gunners.\n\nThe Citizens are set to face Fulham (A), Tottenham Hotspur (A) and West Ham United (H) in their last three fixtures. Meanwhile, Mikel Arteta's side is gearing up to clash against Manchester United (A) and Everton (H) in their last two games.\n\nArsenal and Manchester City's title race explored\n\nWhile Gary Neville was bold to predict that the Premier League title race this season could be over before the final day of the season, it could also go down to the wire.\n\nThe title race was kept going after Manchester City defeated Wolverhampton Wanderers 5-1 on Saturday (May 4), with Erling Haaland scoring four goals in the match. Meanwhile, the Gunners defeated Bournemouth 3-0 on the same day, keeping themselves in the race.\n\nThe Gunners must win both of their upcoming games against United and Everton to compete with Manchester City. If they lose or draw even one game, their title hopes could be in serious jeopardy.\n\nMoreover, if Guardiola's side also wins all three of their remaining games, they will beat Arteta's side to win their fourth consecutive title this season, irrespective of how the Gunners perform.\n\nThe Gunners will stand on 89 points if they win both their remaining games, but City has three games in hand. If they win all three, they will be on 91 points, surpassing Arteta's squad by a narrow margin of two points.\n\nArsenal could win their first league title in 20 years only if Manchester City lose or draw one of their three remaining games.\n\nIf City draws in any of their remaining games and the Gunners win both of theirs, they will both have 89 points. {"uri": "2024-05-345255557", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "22:24:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T22:24:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T21:59:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/arsenal-left-praying-while-man-215937246.html", "title": "'Arsenal left praying while Man City shine as end game nears'", "body": "As Manchester City boss Pep Guardiola rather succinctly put it: \"One week left, three games left. Seven, six or three points, Arsenal will win the Premier League.\"\n\nGuardiola is not placing much faith in Manchester United then, given he expects Arsenal to win every game and the Gunners visit Old Trafford on 12 May.\n\nBut, then, he doesn't have to.\n\nIf City win their final three games they will go into the history books as the first team to win the English title in four successive seasons.\n\nFour Erling Haaland goals against Wolves ensured City navigated their latest obstacle with ease. Now it is on to Craven Cottage and Fulham, a team they have beaten 15 times in a row.\n\nThey finish with West Ham at home. City have not dropped a point at Etihad Stadium against the Hammers since Guardiola arrived in 2016.\n\nIn between comes a trip to Tottenham. City have not scored a Premier League goal or taken a point at Spurs' new stadium. They did win there in the FA Cup this season, though, and Ange Postecoglou's team are in terrible form.\n\nAnd, as Wolves boss Gary O'Neil pointed out, this is the hardest time to play City.\n\n\"Manchester City, in May, when they are chasing down a fourth consecutive Premier League title, are fairly tough,\" he said.\n\n\"They have an incredible focus at this point. History tells you, at this point in the run-in, they are difficult to stop.\"\n\nCity hit form at the right time again\n\nThe one negative for City is that Arsenal's goal difference is better by six, which means they have to win to reach the top. A draw will not do.\n\n\"Goal difference is not possible,\" Guardiola said. \"We cannot draw. We have to take nine points.\"\n\nIn a separate interview with BBC Match of the Day, he added: \"Hopefully, we can come back here in a few days and have the chance against West Ham to come here and win the title.\"\n\nFor City to get to the West Ham game and not have a chance of the title, it would require Arsenal to beat Manchester United and for City to get no more than a point from the Fulham and Tottenham trips.\n\nThat feels unlikely for a team that has put an astonishing run together of 16 wins and four draws since they were beaten at Aston Villa on 6 December.\n\nNot that it should come as a surprise.\n\nLast season, City went on a 16-match unbeaten run, winning 14 times, to take the title before they lost at Brentford on the final day. The year before that, they won 23 times in a run of one defeat in 28. The season before that, they won 17 times in a 19-match unbeaten sequence.\n\n\"When you are coming towards the end of the season, you do think differently,\" former City defender Micah Richards told Sky Sports. \"These games are the most important and that's where City seem to thrive.\"\n\nArsenal 'praying' for help\n\nAs Richards' fellow pundit Jamie Redknapp said, Arsenal's task is straightforward.\n\nThey must win at Old Trafford and then again against Everton on the final day. Anything else is completely out of their hands.\n\nGiven the run Mikel Arteta's side have been on, and the two seasons they have had, few would begrudge the Gunners a first title since 2004.\n\nBut, as Jurgen Klopp and Liverpool have found out, running City close and overhauling them are two different matters.\n\n\"They are an unbelievable team,\" said Arsenal midfielder Declan Rice. \"What I have learned in this title race is that you have to be nearly perfect. They have done that for three years in a row.\n\n\"I have massive respect for what they have done. But we have two games to go and we're praying for something to go our way.\"", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8111651877", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "23:01:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T23:01:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T23:00:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/sport/516009/man-city-arsenal-remain-neck-and-neck-in-premier-league-title-race", "title": "Man City, Arsenal remain neck-and-neck in Premier League title race", "body": "Manchester City remained on course for a fourth successive Premier League title with a ruthless 5-1 win over Wolverhampton Wanderers, hours after Arsenal's 3-0 win over Bournemouth kept them provisionally top of the standings.\n\nErling Haaland scored four goals as City pulled to within a point of Arsenal with a game in hand.\n\nNewcastle United moved into sixth place with a 4-1 victory at Burnley that left the hosts on the brink of relegation.\n\nNottingham Forest moved three points clear of the bottom three with a 3-1 win at Sheffield United, and Brentford and Fulham played a scoreless draw.\n\nHours before City's ruthless victory, Arsenal cleared another hurdle in their hunt for their first league title in 20 years.\n\nA penalty shortly before halftime converted by Bukayo Saka gave Arsenal the lead. Leandro Trossard eased the nerves inside the Emirates with a second goal on 70 minutes and Declan Rice added the third deep into stoppage time.\n\n\"We played probably the best first half we've played all season. We could have gone three, four, five easily. We scored one,\" Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta said.\n\n\"Then credit to Bournemouth they changed things and the game became more open which we wanted to avoid.\"\n\nArsenal next travel to Old Trafford to play Manchester United before hosting Everton on the final day.\n\nIf City felt pressure from Arsenal's win, it did not show as Haaland and the holders ran roughshod over Wolves at the Etihad.\n\n\"Nine (more) points, we will be champions. Seven points, six points, three points, Arsenal will win the Premier League,\" Guardiola said.\n\nHaaland, who boosted his league scoring lead to 25 with the first four-goal haul of his career, scored from the penalty spot in the 12th minute, then doubled City's lead in the 35th when he headed home at the far post from Rodri's cross.\n\nThe 23-year-old converted again from the spot just before halftime. Hwang Hee-chan pulled one back for Wolves in the 53rd but Haaland scored his fourth a minute later. Substitute Julian Alvarez completed City's scoring.\n\nGuardiola's team play away at Fulham and Tottenham Hotspur before closing the season at home to West Ham United.\n\nAlexander Isak scored his 20th league goal of the season to lead Newcastle in their romp over Burnley, keeping alive their hopes of playing European football next season.\n\nCallum Wilson, Sean Longstaff and Bruno Guimaraes also got on the scoresheet on a day soured only slightly by Isak's missed penalty.\n\n\"When we're really aggressive and running forward we are a really good team. It's been there in fits and starts this season, but a really good day and something to build on,\" Longstaff told the BBC.\n\nBurnley could have their relegation confirmed when they travel to Spurs next weekend.\n\nA brace by Callum Hudson-Odoi helped Forest breathe a little easier as they climbed three points above the drop zone, gaining a crucial lead over 18th-placed Luton Town with two games to go for both teams.\n\nSheffield, already relegated, remained bottom with 16 points.\n\n\"It was a big step for us but it's not over yet,\" Forest manager Nuno Espirito Santo said. \"We've still got hard games to play.\"\n\nSheffield took the lead in the 16th minute on a penalty from Ben Brereton Diaz, but the visitors equalised 11 minutes later when Danilo found Hudson-Odoi in the box.\n\nRyan Yates gave Forest the lead with his first ever league goal shortly after the break before Hudson-Odoi fired into the near bottom corner to complete his brace in the 65th minute.\n\nSheffield became the first club to concede 100 goals in a 38-match Premier League season. Swindon Town, who also conceded 100 goals in 1993-94, did so over 42 games.\n\nFulham substitute Raul Jimenez missed a golden chance to settle the West London derby against Brentford in a game of missed chances.\n\nJimenez had been on the field for nine minutes when set up by Adama Traore's cross but, despite having time and space, he sent his 73rd-minute effort sailing over the crossbar.\n\nFulham are 12th in the table, while Brentford are 16th. {"uri": "8111517304", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "19:54:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T19:54:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T19:53:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.greenfieldreporter.com/2024/05/04/haaland-scores-4-in-another-win-for-man-city-arsenal-isnt-going-away-in-the-title-race-though/", "title": "Haaland scores 4 in another win for Man City. Arsenal isn't going away in the title race, though - The Daily Reporter - Greenfield Indiana", "body": "Four goals for Erling Haaland. Another win for Manchester City in its bid to capture an unprecedented fourth straight Premier League crown.\n\nHaaland has now at least a hat trick in six of his 63 matches in England's top flight after converting two penalties either side of a towering header and curling home a sublime finish in City's 5-1 victory over Wolverhampton on Saturday. Julian Alvarez added a late fifth, moments after coming on as a substitute for Haaland.\n\n\"Erling is back to business,\" City manager Pep Guardiola said. \"Penalties are a guarantee but the second and fourth (goals) were unbelievable.\"\n\nThat's six straight wins for the defending champions in their five-month unbeaten streak in the league. Three more wins -- away to Fulham and Tottenham and then at home to West Ham -- and the title is theirs once again.\n\nCity might need to be perfect down the stretch to hold off Arsenal.\n\nThere's no sign of an end-of-season collapse by Mikel Arteta's team this time, with a 3-0 win over Bournemouth in the lunchtime kickoff keeping the pressure on City.\n\nArsenal has four straight wins itself and has retained its one-point lead. City, though, has three games left, one more than Arsenal.\n\nLast season, Arsenal's title challenge faded in the spring as a fast-finishing City clinched a third straight league championship with three games to spare.\n\nTwelve months on and the title race is heading into the final week of the season. Indeed, given the form of the top two, it is likely to be decided in the last round of games on May 19.\n\nBukayo Saka converted a penalty in the 45th minute before second-half goals by Leandro Trossard and Declan Rice gave Arsenal victory at Emirates Stadium.\n\nIt left next-to-last Burnley five points adrift of Forest, which occupies the place directly above the relegation zone.\n\nBurnley has to win both of its remaining games -- away to Tottenham and then at home to Forest on the final day -- to stand a chance of staying up. Even that won't be enough if Forest avoids defeat at West Ham next weekend, given Burnley's goal difference is so much worse than Forest's.\n\nLuton, which drew 1-1 with Everton on Friday, is third from bottom and now three points behind Forest. As it stands, the three teams that were promoted last season are going straight back down to the Championship.\n\nCallum Wilson, Sean Longstaff, Bruno Guimaraes and Alexander Isak all scored for Newcastle, which climbed above Manchester United and into sixth place in its bid to qualify for Europe. Newcastle could even catch Tottenham, which is four points further ahead in fifth ahead of its trip to Liverpool on Sunday.\n\nMan United visits Crystal Palace on Monday.\n\nSheffield United was already sure of being relegated before playing Forest, which came from behind through a double from Callum Hudson-Odoi that came either side of Ryan Yates' goal.\n\nHaaland's four goals have left him in sight of the Golden Boot -- awarded to the league's top scorer -- for the second straight season.\n\nThe Norway striker has 25 for the campaign, five more than Isak and Chelsea's Cole Palmer. Ollie Watkins of Aston Villa is one goal further back.\n\nThere will be a refreshing name in the Premier League next season.\n\nIpswich sealed a return to England's top division for the first time in 22 years after finishing as runner-up on the last day of the second-tier Championship's regular season.\n\nA 2-0 win over Huddersfield saw Ipswich beat Leeds to the second automatic qualification spot, behind Leicester.\n\nLeeds joined Southampton, West Bromwich Albion and Norwich in the playoffs for the third promotion spot. Leeds will play Norwich over two legs and Southampton takes on West Brom.", "source": {"uri": "greenfieldreporter.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Greenfield Daily Reporter"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-345192222", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "19:56:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T19:56:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T16:07:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/05/04/haaland-scores-4-in-another-win-for-man-city-arsenal-isnt-going-away-in-the-title-race-though/", "title": "Haaland scores 4 in another win for Man City. Arsenal isn't going away in the title race, though", "body": "Four goals for Erling Haaland. Another win for Manchester City in its bid to capture an unprecedented fourth straight Premier League crown.\n\nHaaland has now at least a hat trick in six of his 63 matches in England's top flight after converting two penalties either side of a towering header and curling home a sublime finish in City's 5-1 victory over Wolverhampton on Saturday. Julian Alvarez added a late fifth, moments after coming on as a substitute for Haaland.\n\n\"Erling is back to business,\" City manager Pep Guardiola said. \"Penalties are a guarantee but the second and fourth (goals) were unbelievable.\"\n\nThat's six straight wins for the defending champions in their five-month unbeaten streak in the league. Three more wins -- away to Fulham and Tottenham and then at home to West Ham -- and the title is theirs once again.\n\nCity might need to be perfect down the stretch to hold off Arsenal.\n\nThere's no sign of an end-of-season collapse by Mikel Arteta's team this time, with a 3-0 win over Bournemouth in the lunchtime kickoff keeping the pressure on City.\n\nArsenal has four straight wins itself and has retained its one-point lead. City, though, has three games left, one more than Arsenal.\n\nLast season, Arsenal's title challenge faded in the spring as a fast-finishing City clinched a third straight league championship with three games to spare.\n\nTwelve months on and the title race is heading into the final week of the season. Indeed, given the form of the top two, it is likely to be decided in the last round of games on May 19.\n\nBukayo Saka converted a penalty in the 45th minute before second-half goals by Leandro Trossard and Declan Rice gave Arsenal victory at Emirates Stadium.\n\nIt left next-to-last Burnley five points adrift of Forest, which occupies the place directly above the relegation zone.\n\nBurnley has to win both of its remaining games -- away to Tottenham and then at home to Forest on the final day -- to stand a chance of staying up. Even that won't be enough if Forest avoids defeat at West Ham next weekend, given Burnley's goal difference is so much worse than Forest's.\n\nLuton, which drew 1-1 with Everton on Friday, is third from bottom and now three points behind Forest. As it stands, the three teams that were promoted last season are going straight back down to the Championship.\n\nCallum Wilson, Sean Longstaff, Bruno Guimaraes and Alexander Isak all scored for Newcastle, which climbed above Manchester United and into sixth place in its bid to qualify for Europe. Newcastle could even catch Tottenham, which is four points further ahead in fifth ahead of its trip to Liverpool on Sunday.\n\nMan United visits Crystal Palace on Monday.\n\nSheffield United was already sure of being relegated before playing Forest, which came from behind through a double from Callum Hudson-Odoi that came either side of Ryan Yates' goal.\n\nHaaland's four goals have left him in sight of the Golden Boot -- awarded to the league's top scorer -- for the second straight season.\n\nThe Norway striker has 25 for the campaign, five more than Isak and Chelsea's Cole Palmer. Ollie Watkins of Aston Villa is one goal further back.\n\nThere will be a refreshing name in the Premier League next season.\n\nIpswich sealed a return to England's top division for the first time in 22 years after finishing as runner-up on the last day of the second-tier Championship's regular season.\n\nA 2-0 win over Huddersfield saw Ipswich beat Leeds to the second automatic qualification spot, behind Leicester.\n\nLeeds joined Southampton, West Bromwich Albion and Norwich in the playoffs for the third promotion spot. {"uri": "8111473168", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "19:00:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T19:00:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T19:00:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/soccer/article-haaland-scores-four-in-another-win-for-man-city/", "title": "Haaland scores four in another win for Man City", "body": "Four goals for Erling Haaland. Another win for Manchester City in its bid to capture an unprecedented fourth straight Premier League crown.\n\nHaaland has now at least a hat trick in six of his 63 matches in England's top flight after converting two penalties, powering in a header and curling home a sublime finish in City's 5-1 victory over Wolverhampton on Saturday. Julian Alvarez added a late fifth, moments after coming on as a substitute for Haaland.\n\nThat's six straight wins for the defending champions in their five-month unbeaten streak in the league. Three more wins -- away to Fulham and Tottenham and then at home to West Ham -- and the title is theirs once again.\n\nCity might need to be perfect down the stretch to hold off Arsenal.\n\nThere's no sign of an end-of-season collapse by Mikel Arteta's team this time, with a 3-0 win over Bournemouth in the lunchtime kickoff keeping the pressure on City.\n\nArsenal has four straight wins itself and has retained its one-point lead. City, though, has three games left, one more than Arsenal.\n\nLast season, Arsenal's title challenge faded in the spring as a fast-finishing City clinched a third straight league championship with three games to spare.\n\nTwelve months on and the title race is heading into the final week of the season. Indeed, given the form of the top two, it is likely to be decided in the last round of games on May 19.\n\nBukayo Saka converted a penalty in the 45th minute before second-half goals by Leandro Trossard and Declan Rice gave Arsenal victory at Emirates Stadium.\n\nBURNLEY IN TROUBLE\n\nBurnley slipped closer to the drop thanks to its 4-1 loss at home to Newcastle combined with relegation rival Nottingham Forest's 3-1 win at last-place Sheffield United.\n\nIt left next-to-last Burnley five points adrift of Forest, which occupies the place directly above the relegation zone.\n\nBurnley has to win both of its remaining games -- away to Tottenham and then at home to Forest on the final day -- to stand a chance of staying up. Even that won't be enough if Forest avoids defeat at West Ham next weekend, given Burnley's goal difference is so much worse than Forest's.\n\nLuton, which drew 1-1 with Everton on Friday, is third from bottom and now three points behind Forest. As it stands, the three teams that were promoted last season are going straight back down to the Championship.\n\nCallum Wilson, Sean Longstaff, Bruno Guimaraes and Alexander Isak all scored for Newcastle, which climbed above Manchester United and into sixth place in its bid to qualify for Europe. Newcastle could even catch Tottenham, which is four points further ahead in fifth ahead of its trip to Liverpool on Sunday.\n\nMan United visits Crystal Palace on Monday.\n\nSheffield United was already sure of being relegated before playing Forest, which came from behind through a double from Callum Hudson-Odoi that came either side of Ryan Yates' goal.\n\nIn the other match Saturday, Brentford and Fulham drew 0-0.\n\nTOP SCORER RACE\n\nHaaland's four goals have left him in sight of the Golden Boot -- awarded to the league's top scorer -- for the second straight season.\n\nThe Norway striker has 25 for the campaign, five more than Isak and Chelsea's Cole Palmer. Ollie Watkins of Aston Villa is one goal further back.\n\nThere will be a refreshing name in the Premier League next season.\n\nIpswich sealed a return to England's top division for the first time in 22 years after finishing as runner-up on the last day of the second-tier Championship's regular season.\n\nA 2-0 win over Huddersfield saw Ipswich beat Leeds to the second automatic qualification spot, behind Leicester.\n\nLeeds joined Southampton, West Bromwich Albion and Norwich in the playoffs for the third promotion spot. Another win for Manchester City in their bid to capture an unprecedented fourth straight English Premier League crown.\n\nHaaland has now at least a hat trick in six of his 63 matches in England's top flight after converting two penalties, powering in a header and curling home a sublime finish in City's 5-1 victory over Wolverhampton today. Julian Alvarez added a late fifth, moments after coming on as a substitute for Haaland.\n\nThat's six straight wins for the defending champions in their five-month unbeaten streak in the league. Three more wins -- away to Fulham and Tottenham and then at home to West Ham -- and the title is theirs once again.\n\nCity might need to be perfect down the stretch to hold off Arsenal.\n\nThere's no sign of an end-of-season collapse by Mikel Arteta's team this time, with a 3-0 win over Bournemouth in the lunchtime kickoff keeping the pressure on City.\n\nArsenal has four straight wins and has retained their one-point lead. City, though, has three games left, one more than Arsenal.\n\nLast season, Arsenal's title challenge faded in the spring as a fast-finishing City clinched a third straight league championship with three games to spare.\n\nTwelve months on and the title race is heading into the final week of the season. Indeed, given the form of the top two, it is likely to be decided in the last round of games on May 19.\n\nBukayo Saka converted a penalty in the 45th minute before second-half goals by Leandro Trossard and Declan Rice gave Arsenal victory at Emirates Stadium.\n\nBurnley slipped closer to the drop thanks to its 4-1 loss at home to Newcastle combined with relegation rival Nottingham Forest's 3-1 win at last-place Sheffield United.\n\nIt left next-to-last Burnley five points adrift of Forest, which occupies the place directly above the relegation zone.\n\nBurnley has to win both of their remaining games -- away to Tottenham and then at home to Forest on the final day -- to stand a chance of staying up. {"uri": "2024-05-345217007", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "20:52:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T20:52:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T20:37:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.straitstimes.com/sport/football/man-city-arsenal-both-win-in-neck-and-neck-premier-league-title-race", "title": "Man City, Arsenal both win in neck-and-neck Premier League title race", "body": "MANCHESTER, England - Manchester City remained on course for a fourth successive Premier League title with a ruthless 5-1 win over Wolverhampton Wanderers on Saturday, hours after Arsenal's 3-0 win over Bournemouth kept them provisionally top of the standings.\n\nErling Haaland struck four times as Pep Guardiola's team pulled to within a point of Arsenal with a game in hand.\n\nNewcastle United moved into sixth place with a 4-1 victory at Burnley that left the hosts on the brink of relegation. Nottingham Forest moved three points clear of the bottom three with a 3-1 win at Sheffield United, and Brentford and Fulham played a scoreless draw.\n\nHours before City's ruthless victory, Arsenal cleared another hurdle in their hunt for their first league title in 20 years.\n\nA penalty shortly before halftime converted by Bukayo Saka gave Arsenal the lead. Leandro Trossard eased the nerves inside the Emirates with a second goal on 70 minutes and Declan Rice added the third deep into stoppage time.\n\n\"We played probably the best first half we've played all season. We could have gone three, four, five easily. We scored one,\" Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta said.\n\n\"Then credit to Bournemouth they changed things and the game became more open which we wanted to avoid.\"\n\nArsenal next travel to Old Trafford to play Manchester United before hosting Everton on the final day.\n\nIf City felt pressure from Arsenal's win, it did not show as Haaland and the holders ran roughshod over Wolves at the Etihad.\n\n\"Nine (more) points, we will be champions. Seven points, six points, three points, Arsenal will win the Premier League,\" Guardiola said.\n\nHaaland -- who boosted his league scoring lead to 25 with the first four-goal haul of his career -- scored from the penalty spot in the 12th minute, then doubled City's lead in the 35th when he headed home at the far post from Rodri's cross.\n\nThe 23-year-old converted again from the spot just before halftime. Hwang Hee-chan pulled one back for Wolves in the 53rd but Haaland scored his fourth a minute later. Substitute Julian Alvarez completed City's scoring.\n\nGuardiola's team play away at Fulham and Tottenham Hotspur before closing the season at home to West Ham United.\n\nAlexander Isak scored his 20th league goal of the season to lead Newcastle in their romp over Burnley, keeping alive their hopes of playing European football next season.\n\nCallum Wilson, Sean Longstaff and Bruno Guimaraes also got on the scoresheet on a day soured only slightly by Isak's missed penalty.\n\n\"When we're really aggressive and running forward we are a really good team. It's been there in fits and starts this season, but a really good day and something to build on,\" Longstaff told the BBC.\n\nBurnley could have their relegation confirmed when they travel to Spurs next Saturday.\n\nBIG STEP FOR FOREST\n\nA brace by Callum Hudson-Odoi helped Forest breathe a little easier as they climbed three points above the drop zone, gaining a crucial lead over 18th-placed Luton Town with two games to go for both teams.\n\nSheffield, already relegated, remained bottom with 16 points.\n\n\"It was a big step for us but it's not over yet,\" Forest manager Nuno Espirito Santo said. \"We've still got hard games to play.\"\n\nSheffield took the lead in the 16th minute on a penalty from Ben Brereton Diaz, but the visitors equalised 11 minutes later when Danilo found Hudson-Odoi in the box.\n\nRyan Yates gave Forest the lead with his first ever league goal shortly after the break before Hudson-Odoi fired into the near bottom corner to complete his brace in the 65th minute.\n\nSheffield became the first club to concede 100 goals in a 38-match Premier League season. Swindon Town, who also conceded 100 goals in 1993-94, did so over 42 games.\n\nFulham substitute Raul Jimenez missed a golden chance to settle the West London derby against Brentford in a game of missed chances.\n\nJimenez had been on the field for nine minutes when set up by Adama Traore's cross but, despite having time and space, he sent his 73rd-minute effort sailing over the crossbar.\n\nFulham are 12th in the table, while Brentford are 16th. Both teams have two matches remaining. {"uri": "8111665728", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "23:24:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T23:24:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T23:22:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "http://www.gdnonline.com/Details/1311406/Arsenal-keep-pressure-on-Man-City-in-title-race", "title": "Arsenal keep pressure on Man City in title race", "body": "Arsenal's Trossard celebrates scoring their second goal with Rice\n\nManchester City remained on course for a fourth successive Premier League title with a ruthless 5-1 win over Wolverhampton Wanderers yesterday, hours after Arsenal's 3-0 win over Bournemouth kept them provisionally top of the standings.\n\nErling Haaland struck four times as Pep Guardiola's team pulled to within a point of Arsenal with a game in hand.\n\nNewcastle United moved into sixth place with a 4-1 victory at Burnley that left the hosts on the brink of relegation. Nottingham Forest moved three points clear of the bottom three with a 3-1 win at Sheffield United, and Brentford and Fulham played a scoreless draw.\n\nHours before City's ruthless victory, Arsenal cleared another hurdle in their hunt for their first league title in 20 years.\n\nA penalty shortly before halftime converted by Bukayo Saka gave Arsenal the lead. Leandro Trossard eased the nerves inside the Emirates with a second goal on 70 minutes and Declan Rice added the third deep into stoppage time.\n\n\"We played probably the best first half we've played all season. We could have gone three, four, five easily. We scored one,\" Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta said.\n\n\"Then credit to Bournemouth they changed things and the game became more open which we wanted to avoid.\"\n\nArsenal next travel to Old Trafford to play Manchester United before hosting Everton on the final day.\n\nIf City felt pressure from Arsenal's win, it did not show as Haaland and the holders ran roughshod over Wolves at the Etihad.\n\n\"Nine (more) points, we will be champions. Seven points, six points, three points, Arsenal will win the Premier League,\" Guardiola said.\n\nHaaland - who boosted his league scoring lead to 25 with the first four-goal haul of his career - scored from the penalty spot in the 12th minute, then doubled City's lead in the 35th when he headed home at the far post from Rodri's cross.\n\nThe 23-year-old converted again from the spot just before halftime. Hwang Hee-chan pulled one back for Wolves in the 53rd but Haaland scored his fourth a minute later. Substitute Julian Alvarez completed City's scoring.\n\nGuardiola's team play away at Fulham and Tottenham Hotspur before closing the season at home to West Ham United.\n\nAlexander Isak scored his 20th league goal of the season to lead Newcastle in their romp over Burnley, keeping alive their hopes of playing European football next season.\n\nCallum Wilson, Sean Longstaff and Bruno Guimaraes also got on the scoresheet on a day soured only slightly by Isak's missed penalty.\n\n\"When we're really aggressive and running forward we are a really good team. It's been there in fits and starts this season, but a really good day and something to build on,\" Longstaff told the BBC.\n\nBurnley could have their relegation confirmed when they travel to Spurs next Saturday.\n\nA brace by Callum Hudson-Odoi helped Forest breathe a little easier as they climbed three points above the drop zone, gaining a crucial lead over 18th-placed Luton Town with two games to go for both teams.\n\nSheffield, already relegated, remained bottom with 16 points. Sheffield took the lead in the 16th minute on a penalty from Ben Brereton Diaz, but the visitors equalised 11 minutes later when Danilo found Hudson-Odoi in the box.\n\nRyan Yates gave Forest the lead with his first ever league goal shortly after the break before Hudson-Odoi fired into the near bottom corner to complete his brace in the 65th minute.\n\nSheffield became the first club to concede 100 goals in a 38-match Premier League season. Swindon Town, who also conceded 100 goals in 1993-94, did so over 42 games.\n\nFulham substitute Raul Jimenez missed a golden chance to settle the West London derby against Brentford in a game of missed chances.\n\nJimenez had been on the field for nine minutes when set up by Adama Traore's cross but, despite having time and space, he sent his 73rd-minute effort sailing over the crossbar.\n\nFulham are 12th in the table, while Brentford are 16th. What Guardiola and Arteta need to do", "body": "After wins for both Arsenal and Manchester City at the weekend, it's still all to play for in the Premier League title race with just two weekends remaining.\n\nMikel Arteta's side breezed past Bournemouth with a 3-0 home win early on Saturday to remain top of the table as the Gunners go in search of their first league title since the 2003/04 season.\n\nCity, however, kept pace with the league leaders later in the day, with Erling Haaland notching up four goals as Pep Guardiola's side romped to a 5-1 win over Wolves.\n\nThe emphatic result pulled City back within one point of Arsenal and, with a game in hand over the title rivals, the defending champions still have the advantage as they look to become the first side ever to win four consecutive league titles.\n\nWith a game in hand over Arsenal, the task is simple for City - win all three remaining games and they will be crowned champions for a historic fourth successive year.\n\nArsenal, meanwhile, need to win their remaining two games and hope that City slip up in one of their final three games.\n\nArteta's side, though, do have an important six-goal advantage when it comes to goal difference, meaning if City were to draw any of their final three games and Arsenal won their remaining two the trophy, in all likelihood, would head to north London.\n\nArsenal face a potentially tricky visit to Old Trafford next weekend. Erik ten Hag's side put a dagger through Liverpool's title hopes last month and may have another surprise up their sleeve as they look to keep their own European qualification hopes alive.\n\nOn the final day, Arteta's side will host Everton who have enjoyed a resurgent few weeks to steer themselves clear of the relegation zone.\n\nMan City, meanwhile, begin their final three games with an away trip to Fulham before their crunch midweek feature against Ange Posteoglou's Tottenham.\n\nSpurs have caused many an upset against Guardiola's side over the years and also have plenty to play for in the final few games as they hunt down a spot in the top four.\n\nOn the final day, the defending champions are at home for the visit of West Ham whose form - and hopes of another season in Europe - has taken a hit in recent weeks.\n\nShould City beat Fulham on Saturday, the pressure would be firmly on Arsenal to keep the title race alive.\n\nIf the Gunners slip up and lose against Manchester United on Sunday, City would have the chance to win the league against Tottenham in midweek.\n\nHowever, should both teams win their matches next weekend, the title race is guaranteed to go to the final weekend.\n\nWhile still mathematically possible, Liverpool's title hopes are essentially over after their derby-day defeat to Everton and a deflating draw against West Ham.\n\nShould Jurgen Klopp's side win their remaining two games they would reach 84 points, albeit with a far inferior goal difference.\n\nTo win the league, therefore, the Reds would require Arsenal to lose their two remaining games and City to pick up just one point from their final three games.\n\nMORE : Virgil van Dijk speaks out on Liverpool future amid Bayern Munich transfer speculation", "source": {"uri": There's no sign of an end-of-season collapse by...\n\nThe Premier League title race looks to be going to the wire. There's no sign of an end-of-season collapse by Arsenal this time.\n\nKeeping the pressure on Manchester City, Arsenal beat Bournemouth 3-0 in the lunchtime kickoff Saturday for a fourth straight win in the league.\n\nIt pushed Arsenal four points clear of second-place City, which has two games in hand -- the first of which was against Wolverhampton later Saturday.\n\nLast season, Arsenal's title challenge faded in the spring as a fast-finishing City clinched a third straight league championship with three games to spare.\n\nTwelve months on and the title race is heading into the final week of the season. Indeed, given the form of the top two, it is likely to be decided in the last round of games on May 19.\n\nBukayo Saka converted a penalty in the 45th minute before second-half goals by Leandro Trossard and Declan Rice gave Arsenal victory at Emirates Stadium.\n\nBURNLEY IN TROUBLE\n\nBurnley slipped closer to the drop thanks to its 4-1 loss at home to Newcastle combined with relegation rival Nottingham Forest's 3-1 win at last-place Sheffield United.\n\nIt left next-to-last Burnley five points adrift of Forest, which occupies the place directly above the relegation zone.\n\nBurnley has to win both of its remaining games -- away to Tottenham and then at home to Forest on the final day -- to stand a chance of staying up. Even that won't be enough if Forest avoids defeat at West Ham next weekend, given Burnley's goal difference is so much worse than Forest's.\n\nLuton is third from bottom and now three points behind Forest. As it stands, the three teams that were promoted last season are going straight back down to the Championship.\n\nCallum Wilson, Sean Longstaff, Bruno Guimaraes and Alexander Isak all scored for Newcastle, which climbed above Manchester United and into sixth place in its bid to qualify for Europe. Newcastle could even catch Tottenham, which is four points further ahead in fifth ahead of its trip to Liverpool on Sunday.\n\nMan United visits Crystal Palace on Monday.\n\nSheffield United was already sure of being relegated before playing Forest, which came from behind through a double from Callum Hudson-Odoi that came either side of Ryan Yates' goal.\n\nIn the other match Saturday, Brentford and Fulham drew 0-0.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. Neville makes PL title 'twist' claim as he reveals 'fear' in fresh prediction - Football365", "body": "Man Utd legend Gary Neville fears that the Premier League title race between Arsenal and Man City \"could be over a week on Tuesday\".\n\nThe Gunners beat Bournemouth 3-0 in the early kick-off on Saturday to go four points clear before Pep Guardiola's side showed their class by responding with a 5-1 win against Wolves later in the day to wrestle back control of the title race.\n\nArsenal are now one point ahead of Man City but Guardiola's men have a game in hand on their title rivals heading into the final weeks of the campaign.\n\nMan City have Fulham, Tottenham and West Ham to play with Guardiola knowing that they will win the Premier League title for a record fourth time on the bounce if they take maximum points from those three matches.\n\nAnd Neville reckons Arsenal, who play Everton at home on the last day of the season, could see their title hopes come to an end in their penultimate match against Man Utd at Old Trafford on Sunday.\n\nNeville said on his Sky Sports podcast: \"A few weeks ago when I said Arsenal had to be perfect and they have just had that one slip-up against Aston Villa, there's an inevitability of City at this stage of the season, getting the job done, knowing what they need to do.\n\nUNIQUE TO F365: Mediawatch | Mailbox | Winners & Losers | Bespoke Prem tables\n\n\"They have got that difficult game against Spurs on paper in 10 days but the way Spurs are at this moment in time I think it will be difficult for them against a City side playing for the title, it will be a difficult proposition.\n\n\"As I sit here this weekend, Arsenal and City played really well and did their jobs but you wonder where the title race is going to twist. Where is the twist? City don't give you twists.\n\n\"You always said in years gone by, there will be a twist and turn, something will happen, I'm not sure it is going to happen. What normally happens in these moments is if City win on the Saturday, Arsenal drop points on the Sunday and City win the title on the Tuesday.\n\nMORE ON ARSENAL AND MAN CITY FROM F365\n\n\ud83d\udc49 Who are the most creative players of the Premier League season?\n\n\ud83d\udc49 The Premier League's best player is also its best finisher this season\n\n\"That's what normally happens. It may go to the final day and if it does then it means Arsenal have beaten Man United at Old Trafford. If Arsenal go win at Old Trafford that's a hell of a win.\n\n\"I have that fear the title race could be over a week on Tuesday. I want the title race to go to the final day, my fear is it won't if City win on Saturday against Fulham and United take points off Arsenal on the Sunday.\n\n\"Arsenal have already proven they are a {"uri": "8111555241", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "20:43:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T20:43:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T20:42:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.thestar.com.my/sport/football/2024/05/05/soccer-man-city-arsenal-both-win-in-neck-and-neck-premier-league-title-race", "title": "Soccer-Man City, Arsenal both win in neck-and-neck Premier League title race", "body": "MANCHESTER, England (Reuters) - Manchester City remained on course for a fourth successive Premier League title with a ruthless 5-1 win over Wolverhampton Wanderers on Saturday, hours after Arsenal's 3-0 win over Bournemouth kept them provisionally top of the standings.\n\nErling Haaland struck four times as Pep Guardiola's team pulled to within a point of Arsenal with a game in hand.\n\nNewcastle United moved into sixth place with a 4-1 victory at Burnley that left the hosts on the brink of relegation. Nottingham Forest moved three points clear of the bottom three with a 3-1 win at Sheffield United, and Brentford and Fulham played a scoreless draw.\n\nHours before City's ruthless victory, Arsenal cleared another hurdle in their hunt for their first league title in 20 years.\n\nA penalty shortly before halftime converted by Bukayo Saka gave Arsenal the lead. Leandro Trossard eased the nerves inside the Emirates with a second goal on 70 minutes and Declan Rice added the third deep into stoppage time.\n\n\"We played probably the best first half we've played all season. We could have gone three, four, five easily. We scored one,\" Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta said.\n\n\"Then credit to Bournemouth they changed things and the game became more open which we wanted to avoid.\"\n\nArsenal next travel to Old Trafford to play Manchester United before hosting Everton on the final day.\n\nIf City felt pressure from Arsenal's win, it did not show as Haaland and the holders ran roughshod over Wolves at the Etihad.\n\n\"Nine (more) points, we will be champions. Seven points, six points, three points, Arsenal will win the Premier League,\" Guardiola said.\n\nHaaland -- who boosted his league scoring lead to 25 with the first four-goal haul of his career -- scored from the penalty spot in the 12th minute, then doubled City's lead in the 35th when he headed home at the far post from Rodri's cross.\n\nThe 23-year-old converted again from the spot just before halftime. Hwang Hee-chan pulled one back for Wolves in the 53rd but Haaland scored his fourth a minute later. Substitute Julian Alvarez completed City's scoring.\n\nGuardiola's team play away at Fulham and Tottenham Hotspur before closing the season at home to West Ham United.\n\nAlexander Isak scored his 20th league goal of the season to lead Newcastle in their romp over Burnley, keeping alive their hopes of playing European football next season.\n\nCallum Wilson, Sean Longstaff and Bruno Guimaraes also got on the scoresheet on a day soured only slightly by Isak's missed penalty.\n\n\"When we're really aggressive and running forward we are a really good team. It's been there in fits and starts this season, but a really good day and something to build on,\" Longstaff told the BBC.\n\nBurnley could have their relegation confirmed when they travel to Spurs next Saturday.\n\nBIG STEP FOR FOREST\n\nA brace by Callum Hudson-Odoi helped Forest breathe a little easier as they climbed three points above the drop zone, gaining a crucial lead over 18th-placed Luton Town with two games to go for both teams.\n\nSheffield, already relegated, remained bottom with 16 points.\n\n\"It was a big step for us but it's not over yet,\" Forest manager Nuno Espirito Santo said. \"We've still got hard games to play.\"\n\nSheffield took the lead in the 16th minute on a penalty from Ben Brereton Diaz, but the visitors equalised 11 minutes later when Danilo found Hudson-Odoi in the box.\n\nRyan Yates gave Forest the lead with his first ever league goal shortly after the break before Hudson-Odoi fired into the near bottom corner to complete his brace in the 65th minute.\n\nSheffield became the first club to concede 100 goals in a 38-match Premier League season. Swindon Town, who also conceded 100 goals in 1993-94, did so over 42 games.\n\nFulham substitute Raul Jimenez missed a golden chance to settle the West London derby against Brentford in a game of missed chances.\n\nJimenez had been on the field for nine minutes when set up by Adama Traore's cross but, despite having time and space, he sent his 73rd-minute effort sailing over the crossbar.\n\nFulham are 12th in the table, while Brentford are 16th. Both teams have two matches remaining.\n\n(Reporting by Lori Ewing; Editing by Christian Radnedge)", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com.my", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Star "}, "authors": [], There's no sign of an end-of-season collapse by Arsenal this time.\n\nKeeping the pressure on Manchester City, Arsenal beat Bournemouth 3-0 in the lunchtime kickoff Saturday for a fourth straight win in the league.\n\nIt pushed Arsenal four points clear of second-place City, which has two games in hand -- the first of which was against Wolverhampton later Saturday.\n\nLast season, Arsenal's title challenge faded in the spring as a fast-finishing City clinched a third straight league championship with three games to spare.\n\nTwelve months on and the title race is heading into the final week of the season. Indeed, given the form of the top two, it is likely to be decided in the last round of games on May 19.\n\nBukayo Saka converted a penalty in the 45th minute before second-half goals by Leandro Trossard and Declan Rice gave Arsenal victory at Emirates Stadium.\n\nBURNLEY IN TROUBLE\n\nBurnley slipped closer to the drop thanks to its 4-1 loss at home to Newcastle combined with relegation rival Nottingham Forest's 3-1 win at last-place Sheffield United.\n\nIt left next-to-last Burnley five points adrift of Forest, which occupies the place directly above the relegation zone.\n\nBurnley has to win both of its remaining games -- away to Tottenham and then at home to Forest on the final day -- to stand a chance of staying up. Even that won't be enough if Forest avoids defeat at West Ham next weekend, given Burnley's goal difference is so much worse than Forest's.\n\nLuton is third from bottom and now three points behind Forest. As it stands, the three teams that were promoted last season are going straight back down to the Championship.\n\nCallum Wilson, Sean Longstaff, Bruno Guimaraes and Alexander Isak all scored for Newcastle, which climbed above Manchester United and into sixth place in its bid to qualify for Europe. Newcastle could even catch Tottenham, which is four points further ahead in fifth ahead of its trip to Liverpool on Sunday.\n\nMan United visits Crystal Palace on Monday.\n\nSheffield United was already sure of being relegated before playing Forest, which came from behind through a double from Callum Hudson-Odoi that came either side of Ryan Yates' goal.\n\nIn the other match Saturday, Brentford and Fulham drew 0-0.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. Gary O'Neil has done an excellent job with the Wolves this season, but their campaign looks to be ending in mid-table after a brief flirtation with European qualification.\n\nThe Wolves beat City 2-1 in September, but Pep Guardiola's side was without the suspended Rodri for that game, and he will be in the engine room on Saturday.\n\nWith just one point separating Arsenal and City going into the weekend, goal difference could be a deciding factor. Arsenal are currently seven better than their closest rivals, there will be no taking the foot off the gas even if a win has been sealed.\n\nLiverpool's title hopes look to have vanished amid poor recent results and stories of bad-feeling between Jurgen Klopp and Mohamed Salah. It has to hope the top two drop points and beat Tottenham, who travel to Anfield after three consecutive defeats look to have spoiled their chances of overtaking Aston Villa and climbing up to fourth.\n\nVilla travel to face Brighton, whose season is in freefall with no wins and only two goals scored in their last six matches, as rumours continue over possible future destinations for coach Roberto De Zerbi.\n\nAvoiding relegation and hopes of a place in Europe go head-to-head when Burnley entertain Newcastle United, with the home side now only two points behind 17th-placed Nottingham Forest after a run of just one defeat in eight games.\n\nConfidence is high at Burnley after drawing away to Manchester United, but Newcastle will be a tough rival as they look to move into sixth place, with top scorer Alexander Isak in frightening form with seven goals in his last six games.\n\nUnited have a difficult away game against a Crystal Palace side with ten points from the last 12 under new coach Oliver Glasner, and Palace's pacy attack could have fun against United's sometimes slapstick defending.\n\nChelsea's 2-0 win at home to Tottenham on Thursday gives them a slight chance of qualifying for Europe, but first, they have to navigate an always-feisty London derby at home to West Ham.\n\nLuton will move out of the bottom three if they win at home to Everton on Friday night. Everton have nearly ensured their survival after three consecutive wins, but off-pitch financial issues continue to cloud their future, with rumours of possible administration on the horizon.\n\nIf Luton win, that would lift them above Nottingham Forest ahead of Forest's must-win visit to already-relegated Sheffield United, with the home side captained by 20-year-old Oliver Arblaster, the only bright spot in an otherwise grim season for the Blades.\n\nThe remaining game this weekend is a southwest London derby between Brentford and Fulham, who have only local pride to play for.", "source": Pep Guardiola has insisted that Arsenal \"will win\" the Premier League title if his Manchester City side drop points in any of their remaining three matches.\n\nThe Citizens extended their unbeaten run in the top flight to 20 games after putting Wolverhampton Wanderers to the sword 5-1 at the Etihad Stadium on Saturday evening.\n\nErling Haaland stole the headlines with four goals, including a first-half hat-trick, before substitute Julian Alvarez added a fifth in the closing stages to seal three important points for the reigning champions.\n\nGuardiola's side remain second in the Premier League table but have moved back to within one point of leaders Arsenal, who beat Bournemouth 3-0 on home soil earlier in the day.\n\nMan City crucially still have a game in hand and will be crowned champions for a record fourth successive season if they with their final three games, but Guardiola has claimed that Arsenal will come out on top if his side slip up at any stage heading down the home straight.\n\n\u00a9 Reuters\n\nPep Guardiola sends title message to Man City players\n\nGuardiola has suggested that Mikel Arteta's side have a slight advantage in the title race as they boast a superior goal difference - the Gunners' +60 goal difference is six clear of City's +54.\n\nThe Catalan boss has therefore urged his side to take advantage of their game in hand and win all of their remaining fixtures to get the job done.\n\n\"The biggest importance is just two weeks left. Three games. Nine points we will be champions,\" Guardiola told reporters after the victory over Wolves. \"[If we earn only] seven points, six points, three points, Arsenal will win the Premier League.\n\n\"Goal difference is not possible, we cannot draw. The way Arsenal have been playing has been so good and consistent. It's three games, hopefully we win the first and the second and arrive to the third with our Premier League destiny in our own hands.\n\n\"You see the result 5-1 [today] but I don't have the feeling that was really good,\" Guardiola added. \"We lost a lot of balls, simple ones. With teams that make high pressing we can run with Phil [Foden], Kevin [De Bruyne], Julian [Alvarez]. I give a lot of credit to Wolves, the patterns they have. Hwang [Hee-chan], [Matheus] Cunha were always dangerous.\"\n\n\u00a9 Reuters\n\nWhere could Man City drop points in the title run-in?\n\nMan City have been formidable on home soil and their win over Wolves has seen them extend their unbeaten run at the Etihad to 43 games - a new club record surpassing the 42-match streak set between December 1919 and November 1921.\n\nHowever, the Citizens must now prepare for two away fixtures in London, starting off with a trip to Fulham next Saturday before locking horns with Tottenham Hotspur three days later.\n\nMan City will be confident of success against Fulham as they have won each of their last 12 Premier League meetings, including their last five at Craven Cottage.\n\nSuccess at Spurs has not been so easy for the Citizens, though, as they have only won one of their previous six visits to the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium, which opened in 2019.\n\nCity lost their first five games without scoring away against Spurs at their new stadium, but that miserable run came to an end in January when Nathan Ake scored the only goal in a 1-0 victory in the FA Cup fourth round.\n\nGuardiola and co will conclude the season at the Etihad with a clash Bournemouth usually press high and like to attack in numbers, which could leave them exposed to Arsenal's mobility in attack, and with Bukayo Saka and Kai Havertz in excellent form, a home win looks the most likely result. Three points for Arsenal would put pressure on Manchester City in their Saturday evening match at home to Wolverhampton Wolves.\n\nGary O'Neil has done an excellent job with the Wolves this season, but their campaign looks to be ending in mid-table after a brief flirtation with European qualification. The Wolves beat City 2-1 in September, but Pep Guardiola's side was without the suspended Rodri for that game, and he will be in the engine room on Saturday. With just one point separating Arsenal and City going into the weekend, goal difference could be a deciding factor. {"uri": "8109268462", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "08:26:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T08:26:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T08:25:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/sports-news-title-relegation-and-european-spots-in-the-balance-as-premier-league-heads-for-exciting-finale-5937348.html", "title": "Sports News | Title, Relegation and European Spots in the Balance as Premier League Heads for Exciting Finale | LatestLY", "body": "Get latest articles and stories on Sports at LatestLY. The title race is down to two teams. The relegation tussle still involves three. And, the contest for the remaining European qualification positions contains as many as five.\n\nLondon, May 3 (AP) The title race is down to two teams. The relegation tussle still involves three. And, the contest for the remaining European qualification positions contains as many as five.\n\nThe Premier League season is down to its last two weeks and there's still plenty at stake from top to bottom.\n\nAlso Read | RCB vs GT, Bengaluru Weather, Rain Forecast and Pitch Report: Here's How Weather Will Behave for Royal Challengers Bengaluru vs Gujarat Titans IPL 2024 Clash at M Chinnaswamy Stadium.\n\nMeanwhile, the second-tier Championship's regular season finishes on Saturday, with a second automatic promotion spot set to be secured.\n\nHere's a look at what's still to be decided:\n\nAlso Read | RCB vs GT IPL 2024 Preview: Likely Playing XIs, Key Battles, H2H and More About Royal Challengers Bengaluru vs Gujarat Titans Indian Premier League Season 17 Match 52 in Bengaluru.\n\nTITLE\n\nThis time, Arsenal vs Manchester City for the Premier League title looks like going down to the wire.\n\nCity took advantage of a late-season collapse by the Gunners to win the league with three matches to spare in the 2022-23 campaign, but an improved Arsenal might last the course this time round.\n\nArsenal leads by a point with three games to go -- against Bournemouth at home on Saturday, Manchester United away and Everton at home.\n\nCity has four games remaining -- at home to Wolverhampton Wanderers, away to Fulham and Tottenham Hotspur, and at home to West Ham United -- and would capture an unprecedented fourth straight title by winning all of them.\n\nThe pressure is on the defending champion to do that because even just a draw could be fatal. Arsenal has a superior goal difference and, as it stands, would win on that tiebreaker if the teams are equal on points.\n\nAway to Tottenham looks to be the toughest match for City, which has yet to win -- or even score -- in four league games at Tottenham's new stadium that opened in 2019. Spurs fans will have mixed feelings about the May 14 game, because a win for their team could hand Arsenal, Tottenham's fierce north London rival, the title.\n\nA trip to Old Trafford is likely Arsenal's hardest remaining fixture. After all, Liverpool -- until recently the other title contender -- saw its season turned upside down after a loss at United in the FA Cup quarterfinals on March 17 was followed by a costly draw at Old Trafford in the league on April 7.\n\nThe Premier League is the only one of Europe's top five leagues where the title race is still bubbling. Germany's Bundesliga (champions Bayer Leverkusen), Italy's Serie A (Inter Milan) and France's Ligue 1 (Paris Saint-Germain) have been decided, while Real Madrid leads Barcelona by 11 points in Spain's La Liga.\n\nEUROPEAN PLACES\n\nArsenal, City and Liverpool are locked for Champions League qualification, with fourth-place Aston Villa likely to join them. Tottenham is isolated in fifth, the reward for which is Europa League qualification.\n\nThe remaining intrigue, then, revolves around which teams finish in sixth and seventh to likely earn a berth in the Europa Conference League.\n\nManchester United, Newcastle and Chelsea are the teams occupying sixth to eighth places and three points separate them with four games left for each. West Ham and Bournemouth have outside shots in ninth and 10th, respectively.\n\nChelsea is in the best form, having lost just one of its last 11 games -- though that was 5-0 at Arsenal.\n\nIf United drops to eighth, the team has a last chance to get into Europe by winning the FA Cup final against Man City a week after the Premier League finishes.\n\nRELEGATION\n\nThe relegation battle looks like it will go to the final day of the season -- and won't just be determined by what happens on the field.\n\nWith last-place Sheffield United already down, three teams are fighting to avoid the two remaining relegation places: Nottingham Forest (26 points), Luton Town (25 points) and Burnley (24 points).\n\nEach team has three games left and, significantly, two of them meet in the final round when Burnley hosts Forest.\n\nForest's current points total is subject to change, however, because the club has appealed against a four-point deduction for breaching the league's financial rules. The result of that appeal should be known before the end of the season, meaning Forest could recover some points based on the views of an independent panel.\n\nIf Burnley and Luton are also relegated, it means the three teams that came up last year lasted just a season before going back down to the Championship.\n\nPROMOTION\n\nThere's one automatic promotion spot up for grabs heading into the final round of games in the second-tier Championship on Saturday.\n\nLeicester City has already clinched promotion and an immediate return to the Premier League. The team will go up as champions. Ipswich Town or Leeds United will join them.\n\nIpswich, which last played in the top flight in 2002, is currently in second place and three points ahead of third-place Leeds, whose American ownership group includes major-winning golfers Jordan Spieth and Justin Thomas.\n\nIpswich hosts next-to-last Huddersfield Town, and Leeds is at home to fourth-place Southampton.\n\nThe teams placed third to sixth will compete in the playoffs for the third promotion spot. The playoff final is at Wembley Stadium on May 26. The staff, the players, the fans, everyone knows you cannot make one little mistake because you will lose the Premier League.
