Gary O'Neil has done an excellent job with Wolves this season, but their campaign looks to be ending in mid-table after a brief flirtation with European qualification.\n\nWolves beat City 2-1 in September, but Pep Guardiola's side was without the suspended Rodri for that game, and he will be in the engine room on Saturday.\n\nWith just one point separating Arsenal and City going into the weekend, goal difference could be a factor and with Arsenal's currently seven better than their closest rivals, there will be no taking the foot off the gas even if a win has been sealed.\n\nLiverpool's title hopes look to have vanished amid poor recent results and stories of bad-feeling between Jurgen Klopp and Mohamed Salah. It has to hope the top two drop points and beat Tottenham, who travel to Anfield after three consecutive defeats look to have spoiled their chances of overtaking Aston Villa and climbing up to fourth.\n\nVilla travel to face Brighton, whose season is in freefall with no wins and only two goals scored in their last six matches, as rumors continue over possible future destinations for coach Roberto De Zerbi.\n\nAvoiding relegation and hopes of a place in Europe go head-to-head when Burnley entertain Newcastle United, with the home side now only two points behind 17th-placed Nottingham Forest after a run of just one defeat in eight games.\n\nConfidence is high at Burnley after drawing away to Manchester United, but Newcastle will be a tough rival as they look to move into sixth place, with top scorer Alexander Isak in frightening form with seven goals in his last six games.\n\nUnited have a difficult away game against a Crystal Palace side with ten points from the last 12 under new coach Oliver Glasner, and Palace's pacy attack could have fun against United's sometimes slapstick defending.\n\nChelsea's 2-0 win at home to Tottenham on Thursday gives them a slight chance of qualifying for Europe, but first they have to navigate an always-feisty London derby at home to West Ham.\n\nLuton will move out of the bottom three if they win at home to Everton on Friday night. Everton have nearly ensured their survival after three consecutive wins, but off-pitch financial issues continue to cloud their future, with rumors of possible administration on the horizon.\n\nIf Luton win, that would lift them above Nottingham Forest ahead of Forest's must-win visit to already-relegated Sheffield United, with the home side captained by 20-year-old Oliver Arblaster, the only bright spot in an otherwise grim season for the Blades.\n\nThe remaining game this weekend is a southwest London derby between Brentford and Fulham, who have only local pride to play for. \u25a0", There's no sign of an end-of-season collapse by Arsenal this time.\n\nKeeping the pressure on Manchester City, Arsenal beat Bournemouth 3-0 in the lunchtime kickoff Saturday for a fourth straight win in the league.\n\nIt pushed Arsenal four points clear of second-place City, which has two games in hand -- the first of which was against Wolverhampton later Saturday.\n\nLast season, Arsenal's title challenge faded in the spring as a fast-finishing City clinched a third straight league championship with three games to spare.\n\nTwelve months on and the title race is heading into the final week of the season. Indeed, given the form of the top two, it is likely to be decided in the last round of games on May 19.\n\nBukayo Saka converted a penalty in the 45th minute before second-half goals by Leandro Trossard and Declan Rice gave Arsenal victory at Emirates Stadium.\n\nBURNLEY IN TROUBLE\n\nBurnley slipped closer to the drop thanks to its 4-1 loss at home to Newcastle combined with relegation rival Nottingham Forest's 3-1 win at last-place Sheffield United.\n\nIt left next-to-last Burnley five points adrift of Forest, which occupies the place directly above the relegation zone.\n\nBurnley has to win both of its remaining games -- away to Tottenham and then at home to Forest on the final day -- to stand a chance of staying up. Even that won't be enough if Forest avoids defeat at West Ham next weekend, given Burnley's goal difference is so much worse than Forest's.\n\nLuton is third from bottom and now three points behind Forest. As it stands, the three teams that were promoted last season are going straight back down to the Championship.\n\nCallum Wilson, Sean Longstaff, Bruno Guimaraes and Alexander Isak all scored for Newcastle, which climbed above Manchester United and into sixth place in its bid to qualify for Europe. Newcastle could even catch Tottenham, which is four points further ahead in fifth ahead of its trip to Liverpool on Sunday.\n\nMan United visits Crystal Palace on Monday.\n\nSheffield United was already sure of being relegated before playing Forest, which came from behind through a double from Callum Hudson-Odoi that came either side of Ryan Yates' goal.\n\nIn the other match Saturday, {"uri": "8111779073", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "02:37:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T02:37:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T02:34:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.chinadailyasia.com/hk/article/582420", "title": "Man City, Arsenal both win in neck-and-neck Premier League title race", "body": "MANCHESTER, England - Manchester City remained on course for a fourth successive Premier League title with a ruthless 5-1 win over Wolverhampton Wanderers on Saturday, hours after Arsenal's 3-0 win over Bournemouth kept them provisionally top of the standings.\n\nErling Haaland struck four times as Pep Guardiola's team pulled to within a point of Arsenal with a game in hand.\n\nNewcastle United moved into sixth place with a 4-1 victory at Burnley that left the hosts on the brink of relegation. Nottingham Forest moved three points clear of the bottom three with a 3-1 win at Sheffield United, and Brentford and Fulham played a scoreless draw.\n\nHours before City's ruthless victory, Arsenal cleared another hurdle in their hunt for their first league title in 20 years.\n\nA penalty shortly before halftime converted by Bukayo Saka gave Arsenal the lead. Leandro Trossard eased the nerves inside the Emirates with a second goal on 70 minutes and Declan Rice added the third deep into stoppage time.\n\nHaaland -- who boosted his league scoring lead to 25 with the first four-goal haul of his career -- scored from the penalty spot in the 12th minute, then doubled City's lead in the 35th when he headed home at the far post from Rodri's cross\n\n\"We played probably the best first half we've played all season. We could have gone three, four, five easily. We scored one,\" Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta said.\n\n\"Then credit to Bournemouth they changed things and the game became more open which we wanted to avoid.\"\n\nArsenal next travel to Old Trafford to play Manchester United before hosting Everton on the final day.\n\nIf City felt pressure from Arsenal's win, it did not show as Haaland and the holders ran roughshod over Wolves at the Etihad.\n\n\"Nine (more) points, we will be champions. Seven points, six points, three points, Arsenal will win the Premier League,\" Guardiola said.\n\nHaaland -- who boosted his league scoring lead to 25 with the first four-goal haul of his career -- scored from the penalty spot in the 12th minute, then doubled City's lead in the 35th when he headed home at the far post from Rodri's cross.\n\nThe 23-year-old converted again from the spot just before halftime. Hwang Hee-chan pulled one back for Wolves in the 53rd but Haaland scored his fourth a minute later. Substitute Julian Alvarez completed City's scoring.\n\nGuardiola's team play away at Fulham and Tottenham Hotspur before closing the season at home to West Ham United.\n\nAlexander Isak scored his 20th league goal of the season to lead Newcastle in their romp over Burnley, keeping alive their hopes of playing European football next season.\n\nCallum Wilson, Sean Longstaff and Bruno Guimaraes also got on the scoresheet on a day soured only slightly by Isak's missed penalty.\n\n\"When we're really aggressive and running forward we are a really good team. It's been there in fits and starts this season, but a really good day and something to build on,\" Longstaff told the BBC.\n\nBurnley could have their relegation confirmed when they travel to Spurs next Saturday.\n\nBig step for forest\n\nA brace by Callum Hudson-Odoi helped Forest breathe a little easier as they climbed three points above the drop zone, gaining a crucial lead over 18th-placed Luton Town with two games to go for both teams.\n\nSheffield, already relegated, remained bottom with 16 points.\n\n\"It was a big step for us but it's not over yet,\" Forest manager Nuno Espirito Santo said. \"We've still got hard games to play.\"\n\nSheffield took the lead in the 16th minute on a penalty from Ben Brereton Diaz, but the visitors equalised 11 minutes later when Danilo found Hudson-Odoi in the box.\n\nRyan Yates gave Forest the lead with his first ever league goal shortly after the break before Hudson-Odoi fired into the near bottom corner to complete his brace in the 65th minute.\n\nSheffield became the first club to concede 100 goals in a 38-match Premier League season. Swindon Town, who also conceded 100 goals in 1993-94, did so over 42 games.\n\nFulham substitute Raul Jimenez missed a golden chance to settle the West London derby against Brentford in a game of missed chances.\n\nJimenez had been on the field for nine minutes when set up by Adama Traore's cross but, despite having time and space, he sent his 73rd-minute effort sailing over the crossbar.\n\nFulham are 12th in the table, while Brentford are 16th. {"uri": "8110777767", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "07:39:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T07:39:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T07:38:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.naijanews.com/2024/05/04/premier-league-title-arteta-prays-manchester-city-drop-points-for-arsenal/", "title": "Premier League Title: Arteta Prays Manchester City Drop Points For Arsenal", "body": "The manager of Arsenal, Mikel Arteta is hoping that his major Premier League title contender, Manchester City, will drop points for his team.\n\nThe 2023-2024 Premier League title race is now a two-horse race and the battle is between Manchester City and Arsenal.\n\nUnfortunately for the Gunners, the ball is not completely in their court as they are entitled to just 9 points in their remaining three games, while Manchester City have a game in hand which means that they are entitled to 12 points in their remaining four games.\n\nThis means that even if Arsenal win all their remaining games, they can't win the Premier League title this season unless Manchester City suffer at least a defeat in one of their four remaining games.\n\nAhead of the Arsenal vs Bournemouth clash at the Emirates Stadium at 12:30 p.m. later today, Mikel Arteta said: \"In my heart and my soul... this is what I am hoping for, yes.\n\n\"You know what is going on [with my emotions]. You just want to win and to win you need others to drop points and you are hoping for that to happen.\n\n\"And then [after City win] you have to manage your emotion because it doesn't matter what happens on that day.\n\n\"There are still a lot of games and points to play for. You are going to have to perform, prepare and win the next match to maintain that momentum. They have lost their last four league games in a row, conceding 13 goals in the process, to leave them clinging onto fifth rather than hoping for fourth.\n\nAnge Postecoglou's side can still catch Villa in fourth but even wins in their remaining three games wouldn't be enough if Villa win one of their last two. However, their position is not as critical as it recently was and won't be as significant as Arsenal's.\n\nWest Ham are in horrible form, with three defeats and a draw from their last four games that has included shipping five goals to both Chelsea and Crystal Palace. It is threatening to turn sour with no clarity on David Moyes's future with the club reportedly lining up his replacement.\n\nRecent form means they are all but out of the race for European football, even with a home game against Luton to come before the final day. {"uri": "2024-05-344144258", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "15:26:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T15:26:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T15:25:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.transfermarkt.co.uk/five-points-separate-1st-amp-3rd-arsenal-man-city-amp-liverpool-fight-it-out-in-climactic-title-race/view/news/433939", "title": "Five points separate 1st & 3rd - Arsenal, Man City & Liverpool fight it out in climactic title race", "body": "This Premier League season is set go down as one for the ages. The division has already smashed the record for the most goals scored in a Premier League campaign. Last season actually held the previous accolade with 1084 goals, but there have already been 1,096 goals this term with 44 games still left to play. If this term continues with the same scoring rate we have seen so far for the run-in, it's on course for there to be well over 1,200 goals.\n\nWe have been treated to some sensational games of football. Chelsea 4-4 Manchester City, Brighton's 4-2 win against Tottenham, and Manchester United's 3-2 comeback victory against Aston Villa are just some of the enthralling encounters witnessed. There have been numerous games and storylines you simply can't take your eyes off. And the title race looks like it's going to be one of the most thrilling climactic battles in years.\n\nThere's three games to go (four for Man City) and everything to play for. Three teams, who all boast very different qualities will fight it out, although for one team it might be too little too late now. A new look Arsenal currently lead the way, and are vying to win their first title in 20 years under Mikel Arteta, who would become the first ever boss to win the Premier League in his first managerial job. Then come the trophy juggernauts Man City just one point behind with a game in hand. They have won the last three titles under Pep Guardiola, and would become the first ever team to win the English top flight four times in a row if they were to be victorious once again. The 2019/20 champions Liverpool are now five points behind the Gunners, and look all but our of the race, but will still be doing everything possible to help legendary manger J\u00fcrgen Klopp bow out with another Premier League title. Three different, but mesmeric stories could be written over the next few weeks.\n\nArsenal were top of the Premier League for 248 days last season, but ultimately a late capitulation meant they couldn't get over the line in a season where they had been massively overachieving under Arteta. This season they have largely been the chasers. Sloppy points dropped against West Ham and Fulham before the turn of the year left the Gunners behind. However, since the winter break they look right at the top of their game. Arsenal have scored 48 goals and conceded just eight in their 14 league games this calendar year.\n\nArsenal have the best defensive record in the entire Premier League, built around the axis of William Saliba, Gabriel and Declan Rice. They've conceded just 28 goals all season. In the first half of the campaign scoring was an issue, with many believing Arteta's team don't have the natural goalscorer to get them over the line. Although their chance conversion rate has increased drastically in recent months, and it will need to continue in that vein. The North London side also still have a tough away trip to Manchester United to navigate in their run-in, and know even winning all of their remaining fixtures won't be enough if Man City are faultless on their own run-in.\n\nIt's getting to that stage of the season, where everybody knows what to expect from Guardiola's City. Wins, wins and more wins. Last season, the Sky Blues went on a 12 game winning run to wrestle the title from Arsenal. A few years back it was the same story, as they made up a seven point deficit on Liverpool in the 2018/19 season, winning all of their last 10 matches. They are currently a point behind the leaders Arsenal, but with a game in hand are now firm favourites to retain the title. Four wins from four and they are champions again.\n\nTheir title rivals Arsenal and Liverpool (to a lesser extent) however, may take some hope in that Guardiola's team have the worst goals conceded per game rate this season that they have ever had under the Spaniard. That's including Guardiola's first term in charge where Man City finished third. Their recent defeat to Real Madrid in the Champions League could also deflate the team. Nevertheless, having the duo of Kevin De Bruyne and Erling Haaland back fit and firing, as well as the potent form of Phil Foden will be radiating fear to City's challengers.\n\nLiverpool have now lost four Premier League games this season - two in the last three games, and have won just one of their five matches. The defeat to Tottenham back in May was mired in controversy after a VAR error denied a Luis D\u00edaz goal. The other at Arsenal slightly more worrying for Liverpool as they were outclassed by the Gunners. However, on the whole, Liverpool have looked closer to their energetic best this season with a rejuvenated midfield after the additions of Alexis Mac Allister and Dominik Szoboszlai. They've already lifted the first domestic silverware of the season, winning the EFL Cup with a depleted squad.\n\nAfter the news emerged in January that manager Klopp would be stepping down at the end of the season after nine years at the helm, the motivation to win it for the German will be sky high from both the players and the fans. However, their recent implosion which has seen them lose to Atalanta in their Europa League quarter-final, and lose the Meryseyside derby may have some supporters only hoping now rather than expecting.\n\nMan City champions - how the title race would finish based on each managers ppg against remaining opponents\n\nWith the title race so close between three great teams going into the closing stages, there's been lots of talks of supercomputers and algorithms to try and work out who will be Premier League champion come May. And here at Transfermarkt we've decided to weigh in ourselves. Using stats from our database, we have calculated the average points per game ratio of each of the three managers against their seven remaining opponents in the Premier League. Those results leave Guardiola with 2.31ppg against Man City's remaining opponents, Klopp with 2.29ppg against Liverpool's remaining opponents, and Arteta with 2.03ppg against Arsenal's remaining opponents.\n\nWe have then multiplied those numbers by the remaining games each clubs has left (3 for Arsenal & Liverpool and 4 for Man City) and then rounded to the nearest point. It means Man City would take 9 points from the remaining 12 available, leaving them on 88 points. Arsenal would take 6 points from the remaining 9 available, leaving them on 86 points in second. Liverpool would then take 7 from a possible 9 points and finish third with 82 points. It's of course still if's and buts. However, it will be interesting to see if history repeats itself, and how much of a factor these managers' historic records against the teams they play on the run-in will have on who is crowned Where is the twist? City don't give you twists.\"\n\nNeville continued: \"You always said in years gone by: 'There will be a twist and turn, something will happen'. {"uri": "2024-05-344575378", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "03:36:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T03:36:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T03:36:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.thisdaylive.com/index.php/2024/05/04/can-wolves-bournemouth-halt-city-arsenal-title-charge", "title": "Can Wolves, Bournemouth, Halt City, Arsenal Title Charge?", "body": "With third placed Liverpool more or less out of contention, defending champions, Manchester City and leaders, Arsenal will today take another step in their Premier League title charge as the hosts take on Wolves and Bournemouth respectively. On paper, the Citizens and the Gunners should take the three points with relative ease, but any of the visitors could be a banana peel\n\nSeeking to remain within touching distance of Premier League leaders, Arsenal, reigning champions, Manchester City welcome Wolverhampton Wanderers to the Etihad Stadium this evening.\n\nThe Citizens will be out for revenge against the Old Gold after they suffered a 2-1 defeat in the reverse fixture at Molineux almost eight months ago.\n\nThree days after cruising to a statement 4-0 victory at Brighton & Hove Albion, Man City picked up maximum points in Pep Guardiola's 300th Premier League game when they secured a 2-0 win over Nottingham Forest at the City Ground last weekend.\n\nMan City could find themselves four points adrift of title rivals Arsenal at the summit if the Gunners beat Bournemouth in an earlier kickoff today, but the Citizens will then have two games in hand and can reduce the gap at the top to just one point with success over Wolves.\n\nAfter three consecutive away matches, Man City will welcome a return to the Etihad where they have put together an impressive 42-game unbeaten run across all competitions, matching a club record set between 1919 and 1921 - avoiding defeat today would see the Citizens break this record outright.\n\nGuardiola and co, who have also not lost home or away in their last 31 matches in all tournaments will be confident of success against a Wolves side whom they have beaten in seven of their last eight home league meetings, scoring 19 goals in the process.\n\nAfter seven games without a win in all competitions, Wolves edged past relegation-threatened Luton Town by a 2-1 scoreline at Molineux last weekend to boost their chances of securing a top-half finish in the Premier League.\n\nGary O'Neil, who will not be in the dugout after being handed a one-match touchline ban by the Football Association for his conduct after last month's defeat by West Ham United, now sees his side sitting 11th in the Premier League table.\n\nAfter beginning 2024 with a five-game unbeaten run away from home, Wolves have since failed to come out on top in any of their last four matches on the road and they will end the campaign with arguably the two toughest Premier League trips to Man City and Liverpool.\n\nThe Old Gold have lost 18 of their last 20 Premier League away matches against teams in the top two, but one of those victories during this run was at Man City (0-2) in October 2019. They are also one of only three top-flight teams to condemn the champions to defeat this season, so there is reason for O'Neil's men to be confident of pulling off an upset today.\n\nMeanwhile, bidding to temporarily go four points clear at the top of the Premier League standings, Arsenal kick off today's action with the visit of Bournemouth to the Emirates Stadium for the lunchtime kickoff.\n\nThe Gunners staved off a second-half Tottenham Hotspur fightback in an enthralling 3-2 North London derby win last weekend, while the Cherries hit Brighton & Hove Albion for three without reply.\n\nPainful flashbacks to the capitulations of 12 months ago crossed the minds of Gooners last Sunday, where after Bukayo Saka, Kai Havertz and a Pierre-Emile Hojbjerg own goal gave them a seemingly unassailable 3-0 lead over Tottenham, their bitter foes came roaring back.\n\nDavid Raya and Declan Rice's blunders allowed Cristian Romero and Son Heung-min to threaten an almighty turnaround, but the latter's penalty ultimately came too late for the Lilywhites to salvage anything from the heated derby, as Arsenal just about emerged unscathed from that five-goal classic.\n\nThanks to their latest victory in a game that Saka admitted his side may not have won last year, Arsenal have retained their vulnerable one-point advantage over Manchester City, but owing to the champions' game in hand, perfection may still not be enough to end their 20-year title drought.\n\nWith Liverpool more or less out of the race, though, it is a nerve-jangling straight shootout for glory between Mikel Arteta and his erstwhile employers, who do not play again until evening and will therefore fall further behind the Gunners if the Emirates giants make it four top-flight wins on the bounce this weekend.\n\nSix of Arsenal's seven Premier League home matches in 2024 so far have ended in triumph, the outlier being April's alarming 2-0 loss to Aston Villa, and on the back of being on the right end of a 3-2 scoreline versus Tottenham, it is only appropriate that Arsenal reunite with Bournemouth after last year's Emirates extravaganza.\n\nSafely marooned in mid-table as the campaign enters its dying embers, Bournemouth followed up their 1-0 beating of Wolves with an emphatic South Coast success against Brighton, where one of Andoni Iraola's attacking marksmen stole the show.\n\nLeaving the relegation dogfight well and truly behind, Iraola's men are smack-bang in the middle of the standings in 10th spot on account of gleaning 48 points - their highest-ever Premier League total and European qualification remains a mathematical possibility with just three games left to go.\n\nThe work of Iraola and his coaching staff will not go unnoticed either way, but Bournemouth were demolished 4-0 by Arsenal on home soil back in September and blew a 2-0 lead in this fixture last March, where Reiss Nelson's 97th-minute winner sparked perhaps the wildest celebrations the Emirates has ever seen.", "source": {"uri": "thisdaylive.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "THISDAYLIVE"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8111360160", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "16:56:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T16:56:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T16:55:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13382927/Arsenal-taking-Premier-League-title-race-wire-extending-winning-streak.html", "title": "Arsenal is taking the Premier League title race to the wire after...", "body": "The Premier League title race looks to be going to the wire. There's no sign of an end-of-season collapse by Arsenal this time.\n\nKeeping the pressure on Manchester City, Arsenal beat Bournemouth 3-0 in the lunchtime kickoff Saturday for a fourth straight win in the league.\n\nIt pushed Arsenal four points clear of second-place City, which has two games in hand - the first of which was against Wolverhampton later Saturday.\n\nLast season, Arsenal's title challenge faded in the spring as a fast-finishing City clinched a third straight league championship with three games to spare.\n\nTwelve months on and the title race is heading into the final week of the season. Indeed, given the form of the top two, it is likely to be decided in the last round of games on May 19.\n\nBukayo Saka converted a penalty in the 45th minute before second-half goals by Leandro Trossard and Declan Rice gave Arsenal victory at Emirates Stadium.\n\nArsenal's Bukayo Saka, right, celebrates with teammates after scoring his side's opening goal during the English Premier League soccer match between Arsenal and Bournemouth at Emirates Stadium in London, England, Saturday, May 4, 2024. (AP Photo/Frank Augstein)\n\nBURNLEY IN TROUBLE\n\nBurnley slipped closer to the drop thanks to its 4-1 loss at home to Newcastle combined with relegation rival Nottingham Forest's 3-1 win at last-place Sheffield United.\n\nIt left next-to-last Burnley five points adrift of Forest, which occupies the place directly above the relegation zone.\n\nBurnley has to win both of its remaining games - away to Tottenham and then at home to Forest on the final day - to stand a chance of staying up. Even that won't be enough if Forest avoids defeat at West Ham next weekend, given Burnley's goal difference is so much worse than Forest's.\n\nLuton is third from bottom and now three points behind Forest. As it stands, the three teams that were promoted last season are going straight back down to the Championship.\n\nCallum Wilson, Sean Longstaff, Bruno Guimaraes and Alexander Isak all scored for Newcastle, which climbed above Manchester United and into sixth place in its bid to qualify for Europe. Newcastle could even catch Tottenham, which is four points further ahead in fifth ahead of its trip to Liverpool on Sunday.\n\nMan United visits Crystal Palace on Monday.\n\nSheffield United was already sure of being relegated before playing Forest, which came from behind through a double from Callum Hudson-Odoi that came either side of Ryan Yates' goal.\n\nIn the other match Saturday, Brentford and Fulham drew 0-0.\n\nSteve Douglas is at https://twitter.com/sdouglas80\n\nAP soccer: https://apnews.com/hub/soccer\n\nArsenal's Bukayo Saka celebrates after scoring his side's opening goal during the English Premier League soccer match between Arsenal and Bournemouth at Emirates Stadium in London, England, Saturday, May 4, 2024. {"uri": "8111578947", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "21:13:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T21:13:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T21:12:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/articles/cx7dw56358vo", "title": "Premier League title race: 'Arsenal left praying while Man City shine as end game nears'", "body": "As Manchester City boss Pep Guardiola rather succinctly put it: \"One week left, three games left. Nine points and we will be champions. Seven, six or three points, Arsenal will win the Premier League.\"\n\nGuardiola is not placing much faith in Manchester United then, given he expects Arsenal to win every game and the Gunners visit Old Trafford on 12 May.\n\nBut, then, he doesn't have to.\n\nIf City win their final three games they will go into the history books as the first team to win the English title in four successive seasons.\n\nFour Erling Haaland goals against Wolves ensured City navigated their latest obstacle with ease. Now it is on to Craven Cottage and Fulham, a team they have beaten 15 times in a row.\n\nThey finish with West Ham at home. City have not dropped a point at Etihad Stadium against the Hammers since Guardiola arrived in 2016.\n\nIn between comes a trip to Tottenham. City have not scored a Premier League goal or taken a point at Spurs' new stadium. {"uri": "8114209362", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "17:27:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T17:27:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T17:25:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.football.london/arsenal-fc/news/supercomputer-predicts-premier-league-title-29122116", "title": "Supercomputer hands Arsenal Man City Premier League title race verdict", "body": "Arsenal still sit in the driving seat to win the Premier League title this season after their 3-0 win over Bournemouth last weekend but with Manchester City still holding a precious game in hand, it's still all to play for.\n\nWith just one point currently separating the two sides, Mikel Arteta's men are not only vying to secure their first league title in over 20 years but also trying to exact revenge on Pep Guardiola's Citizens after last season's dramatic title race which saw the Gunners stumble in the final few weeks of the season to hand Man City their fourth Premier League in a row.\n\nHowever, there's been no sign of that happening in recent weeks, with just one defeat in their last 16 league matches coming at the hands of Unai Emery's Aston Villa. Their win over the Cherries on Saturday handed them a six-goal cushion in terms of goal difference over City, but the Gunners will still need to 'win-out' and hope that Guardiola's men drop points in their final three matches of the season in order to have a chance at winning the title.\n\nAs for Jurgen Klopp's Liverpool, a torrid rut in form over the past few weeks has seen their title hopes all but dashed with just two wins in their last five - including a 2-0 Merseyside derby loss to Everton at Goodison Park - condemning them to an almost-guaranteed third-place finish in the German's final season in charge at Anfield.\n\nAhead of Arsenal's vital clash with a struggling Manchester United side on Sunday afternoon, Bettingexpert.com's supercomputer, BETSiE, ran it's algorithm to predict how the 2023-24 Premier League title race will pan out. The probability model - which takes into account all match results from last season (across all competitions), pre-season results and the current season - projects the title race based on both pre-season expectations and xG earned both for and against during the season.\n\nWith the supercomputer simulating the Premier League season 100,000 times, the Gunners were given a 44.9 percent chance to win the league title from this point on while Man City's winning probability stands at 55.1%. The final projected table sees Man City sat on an average of 88.7 points while Arsenal finished on an average of 87.8 points, meaning the title race went down to less than a single point.\n\nREAD MORE: Arsenal title boost emerges after Manchester City goal difference reality eases fears\n\nREAD MORE: Mikel Arteta admits new Arsenal approach to referees amid Kai Havertz and Bukayo Saka verdicts\n\nThe supercomputer still has Arsenal finishing with a better goal difference than Man City, but in real life, the Gunners will need them to drop points for that to have an impact on how the title race finishes - a scenario which the supercomputer predicts won't happen.\n\nWith trips to Fulham and Tottenham before a home game against West Ham as their final match of the season, it's certainly possible for Guardiola's side to simply win all three and lift their fifth consecutive Premier League title but Arsenal boss Arteta is still insisting his side will be the ones to lift the trophy at the end of the season.\n\nWhen asked how he's feeling ahead of their final two matches of the season with the title race still in the balance, he admitted: \"Very excited. {"uri": "8111618650", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "22:12:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T22:12:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T22:07:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://theprint.in/sport/soccer-man-city-arsenal-both-win-in-neck-and-neck-premier-league-title-race/2070422/", "title": "Soccer-Man City, Arsenal both win in neck-and-neck Premier League title race", "body": "Newcastle United moved into sixth place with a 4-1 victory at Burnley that left the hosts on the brink of relegation. Nottingham Forest moved three points clear of the bottom three with a 3-1 win at Sheffield United, and Brentford and Fulham played a scoreless draw.\n\nHours before City's ruthless victory, Arsenal cleared another hurdle in their hunt for their first league title in 20 years.\n\nA penalty shortly before halftime converted by Bukayo Saka gave Arsenal the lead. Leandro Trossard eased the nerves inside the Emirates with a second goal on 70 minutes and Declan Rice added the third deep into stoppage time.\n\n\"We played probably the best first half we've played all season. We could have gone three, four, five easily. We scored one,\" Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta said.\n\n\"Then credit to Bournemouth they changed things and the game became more open which we wanted to avoid.\"\n\nArsenal next travel to Old Trafford to play Manchester United before hosting Everton on the final day.\n\nIf City felt pressure from Arsenal's win, it did not show as Haaland and the holders ran roughshod over Wolves at the Etihad.\n\n\"Nine (more) points, we will be champions. Seven points, six points, three points, Arsenal will win the Premier League,\" Guardiola said.\n\nHaaland -- who boosted his league scoring lead to 25 with the first four-goal haul of his career -- scored from the penalty spot in the 12th minute, then doubled City's lead in the 35th when he headed home at the far post from Rodri's cross.\n\nThe 23-year-old converted again from the spot just before halftime. Hwang Hee-chan pulled one back for Wolves in the 53rd but Haaland scored his fourth a minute later. Substitute Julian Alvarez completed City's scoring.\n\nGuardiola's team play away at Fulham and Tottenham Hotspur before closing the season at home to West Ham United.\n\nAlexander Isak scored his 20th league goal of the season to lead Newcastle in their romp over Burnley, keeping alive their hopes of playing European football next season.\n\nCallum Wilson, Sean Longstaff and Bruno Guimaraes also got on the scoresheet on a day soured only slightly by Isak's missed penalty.\n\n\"When we're really aggressive and running forward we are a really good team. It's been there in fits and starts this season, but a really good day and something to build on,\" Longstaff told the BBC.\n\nBurnley could have their relegation confirmed when they travel to Spurs next Saturday.\n\nA brace by Callum Hudson-Odoi helped Forest breathe a little easier as they climbed three points above the drop zone, gaining a crucial lead over 18th-placed Luton Town with two games to go for both teams.\n\nSheffield, already relegated, remained bottom with 16 points.\n\n\"It was a big step for us but it's not over yet,\" Forest manager Nuno Espirito Santo said. \"We've still got hard games to play.\"\n\nSheffield took the lead in the 16th minute on a penalty from Ben Brereton Diaz, but the visitors equalised 11 minutes later when Danilo found Hudson-Odoi in the box.\n\nRyan Yates gave Forest the lead with his first ever league goal shortly after the break before Hudson-Odoi fired into the near bottom corner to complete his brace in the 65th minute.\n\nSheffield became the first club to concede 100 goals in a 38-match Premier League season. Swindon Town, who also conceded 100 goals in 1993-94, did so over 42 games.\n\nFulham substitute Raul Jimenez missed a golden chance to settle the West London derby against Brentford in a game of missed chances.\n\nJimenez had been on the field for nine minutes when set up by Adama Traore's cross but, despite having time and space, he sent his 73rd-minute effort sailing over the crossbar.\n\nFulham are 12th in the table, while Brentford are 16th. Both teams have two matches remaining.\n\n(Reporting by Lori Ewing; Editing by Christian Radnedge)", "source": {"uri": "theprint.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "ThePrint"}, "authors": [{"uri": Guardiola is convinced the Gunners will win their remaining two games, including Sunday's visit to Manchester United, meaning City must take maximum points to retain the title.\n\nCity can go top and put the pressure on Arsenal by winning at Fulham on Saturday, 24 hours before Mikel Arteta's side play their penultimate game at Old Trafford.\n\nBut Guardiola says playing before or after Arsenal makes no difference, with the City boss adamant his side must win their remaining games.\n\n\"If we play Fulham before or after Arsenal, we still have to win,\" said Guardiola. \"And Arsenal know they have to win.\n\n\"Not just the the players, the staff, the fans - everyone knows you cannot make one little mistake, because you will lose the Premier League.\n\n\"They know it, we know it, with what happened with Liverpool in the past. We arrived here (at Wolves ) and the players knew 'guys, if we don't win, Ciao, Ciao, bye-bye, next season we see each other'.\n\n\"It's not complicated. It doesn't matter if we play before or after. Hopefully we win against Fulham, then Arsenal will play at Old Trafford, where they [United] are playing for the Europa League.\n\n\"But I said, if we don't win we won't be champions, so when that happens it's easier.\" On Arsenal, Guardiola said: \"You see the level of consistency since the winter break, the way they're playing.\n\n\"It's not the fact that they're winning, it's the way they play, so you smell that they're not going to lose in the games they have left. There's no sign of an end-of-season collapse by Arsenal this time.\n\nKeeping the pressure on Manchester City, Arsenal beat Bournemouth 3-0 in the lunchtime kickoff Saturday for a fourth straight win in the league.\n\nIt pushed Arsenal four points clear of second-place City, which has two games in hand -- the first of which was against Wolverhampton later Saturday.\n\nLast season, Arsenal's title challenge faded in the spring as a fast-finishing City clinched a third straight league championship with three games to spare.\n\nTwelve months on and the title race is heading into the final week of the season. Indeed, given the form of the top two, it is likely to be decided in the last round of games on May 19.\n\nBurnley slipped closer to the drop thanks to its 4-1 loss at home to Newcastle combined with relegation rival Nottingham Forest's 3-1 win at last-place Sheffield United.\n\nIt left next-to-last Burnley five points adrift of Forest, which occupies the place directly above the relegation zone.\n\nBurnley has to win both of its remaining games -- away to Tottenham and then at home to Forest on the final day -- to stand a chance of staying up. Even that won't be enough if Forest avoids defeat at West Ham next weekend, given Burnley's goal difference is so much worse than Forest's.\n\nLuton is third from bottom and now three points behind Forest. {"uri": "8110722327", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-04", "time": "06:49:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-04T06:49:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-04T06:47:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://blueprint.ng/premier-league-week-36-preview-arsenal-manchester-city-in-action-as-title-race-heats-up/", "title": "Premier League week 36 preview: Arsenal, Manchester City in action as title race heats up", "body": "Arsenal will continue their title push when they host Bournemouth at the Emirates Stadium.\n\nThe Gunners emerged victorious in the North London Derby against Tottenham, albeit with a scare, as a 3-0 halftime lead was nearly blown away, with Mikel Arteta's men eventually running out 3-2 winners.\n\nThey currently lie top of the table with 80 points, a point ahead of Manchester City, but with the Citizens having a game in hand, all they can do is win their remaining games and hope for a City slip up.\n\nThey are well placed to pick up all three points here, as they have won 10 of their last 13 meetings with the Cherries, losing just once in 2018. They were 4-0 winners at the Vitality Stadium earlier in the season, and will now look to do the double.\n\nManchester City will host Wolves at the Etihad Stadium, as they aim to keep up their winning run of form.\n\nThe Citizens secured a 2-0 win at Nottingham Forest to stay within touching distance of Arsenal, and boasting a game in hand, will go on to lift a fourth straight league title should they prevail in their remaining league fixtures.\n\nStanding in their way is a Wolves side that they have beaten in six of the last seven meetings, though the one defeat came earlier in the season at the Molineux. However, with City at home and with much to play for, it will take an almighty effort for Gary O'Neill's side to derail their title charge.\n\nBurnley and Newcastle United clash at Turf Moor, with both teams eyeing the points for different reasons.\n\nBurnley are 19th on the table, two points from safety and picked up a crucial point in a 1-1 draw with Manchester United last time out.\n\nThey face a tough task against Newcastle though, who they have picked up just two wins in the last 14 games.\n\nThe Toon Army are firmly in the race for Europa League qualification, and having thumped Sheffield United 5-1 in the last game, with star man Alexander Isak netting twice, will now look to secure back to back wins.\n\nBrentford will hope to improve their 16th place standing in the league when they host Fulham at the Gtech Community Stadium.\n\nWith just a point keeping them out of the relegation zone, Nottingham Forest will head to Bramall Lane to face an already relegated Sheffield United outfit in a game that could have catastrophic results if they lose.\n\nOn Sunday, Liverpool will target a return to winning ways when Tottenham make the trip to Anfield.\n\nThe Reds' title push seems to have come to a halt after a poor run of results, with the latest being a 2-2 draw against West Ham. That has left them five points behind leaders Arsenal, with just three games left to play.\n\nThey will seek to end the season strong nevertheless, and what better way to start than beating a Spurs outfit who secured a win at Anfield earlier in the season in controversial circumstances.\n\nAnge Postecoglu's men have lost their last two league games, both London Derbies to Arsenal and Chelsea, shipping in five goals in the process. Prior to the win at Anfield earlier in the season, which ended the Reds' 12 game unbeaten in this fixture, the Lilywhites had not prevailed in the previous four. The odds are stacked against them going into this.\n\nBrighton will hope to end a dreadful run of form which has seen them go six games without a win when they tackle Aston Villa at the Amex Stadium. Villa lie fourth, seven points clear of Tottenham in the race for Champions League football, but come into this on the back of a disappointing 4-2 loss to Olympiakos in the Europa Conference League on Thursday. With the return leg due to come next week, the Lions will have to focus on picking up points here first.\n\nChelsea will take on West Ham at Stamford Bridge, as their push for a European spot gains momentum. The Blues are unbeaten in their last four home games and have won seven of their last 10 matches.\n\nA victory here will see them go level on points with sixth placed Man United, who are not in action until Monday.\n\nWest Ham are two points behind the Blues and were 3-1 winners when they faced off at the London Stadium earlier in the season. (Danny Lawson/PA via AP)\n\nThe Premier League title race looks to be going to the wire. There's no sign of an end-of-season collapse by Arsenal this time.\n\nKeeping the pressure on Manchester City, Arsenal beat Bournemouth 3-0 in the lunchtime kickoff Saturday for a fourth straight win in the league.\n\nIt pushed Arsenal four points clear of second-place City, which has two games in hand -- the first of which was against Wolverhampton later Saturday.\n\nLast season, Arsenal's title challenge faded in the spring as a fast-finishing City clinched a third straight league championship with three games to spare.\n\nTwelve months on and the title race is heading into the final week of the season. Indeed, given the form of the top two, it is likely to be decided in the last round of games on May 19.\n\nBurnley slipped closer to the drop thanks to its 4-1 loss at home to Newcastle combined with relegation rival Nottingham Forest's 3-1 win at last-place Sheffield United.\n\nIt left next-to-last Burnley five points adrift of Forest, which occupies the place directly above the relegation zone.\n\nBurnley has to win both of its remaining games -- away to Tottenham and then at home to Forest on the final day -- to stand a chance of staying up. Even that won't be enough if Forest avoids defeat at West Ham next weekend, given Burnley's goal difference is so much worse than Forest's.\n\nLuton is third from bottom and now three points behind Forest. Arsenal have Manchester United and Everton remaining, while City still have to face Fulham, Tottenham Hotspur and West Ham.\n\nAt the bottom of the table, Sheffield United have already been relegated. However, the remaining two teams that will drop to the Championship are still to be determined with Nottingham Forest (29), Luton Town (26) and Burnley (24) all still in with a mathematical chance of staying up.\n\nLeicester City and Ipswich Town - back in the Premier League for the first time in 22 years - have already been promoted, with Leeds United, Southampton, West Bromwich Albion and Norwich City contesting the playoffs for the final spot.\n\nHow close the English Premier League has been just goes to show you how dominant the unbeaten Sundowns have been on home soil. {"uri": "8111939987", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "06:10:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T06:10:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T06:10:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.football.london/arsenal-fc/news/triple-arsenal-title-boost-hope-29115177", "title": "Arsenal have triple Premier League title hope for Man City slip-up", "body": "It is incredibly disheartening after watching one of the most dominant Arsenal performances to secure an important three points and leave only two games to go for your main rivals to ease, or rather, romp to victory immediately after. That's exactly what Manchester City did against Wolves but Liverpool fans might say, 'Get used to it!'\n\nAs the fourth and fifth goals went in at the Etihad Stadium the reality became glaringly clear and suddenly you look back on where points might have been accrued. Be it the injustice of Villa Park, whether the ball did indeed go out of play against Newcastle United and West Ham, or the flukiness of Chelsea's two goals at Stamford Bridge and Jorginho's gift against Tottenham.\n\nYet, when you realise Arsenal have taken 43 of a possible 48 points in 2024, you realise just how vast the challenge is to beat Pep Guardiola and his club. Taking the title race to the last day, which Arsenal will guarantee occurs should they beat Manchester United, would be a greater push for the league than they managed last year.\n\nThere remains reason for optimism in the final three matches that City have to play. First comes Fulham, which remains one of the arenas for the most disappointing Arsenal performance of the season.\n\nYet, the Cottagers still needed to come through on the day and Marco Silva's side have managed to take five points off the Gunners this season. This giant-humbling of course gives reason to believe they could indeed complete another against City in just under a week's time - that said it's probably best not to look up how Fulham faired the last time the two met if you'd like to maintain that said optimism.\n\nThen comes... Tottenham. Yes, Arsenal's title hopes could rest on their bitter North London rivals securing an unlikely result against City in North London.\n\nREAD MORE: What Ben White did at corners against Bournemouth as Arsenal advice takes effect\n\nREAD MORE: Arsenal vs Bournemouth highlights: Rice, Trossard and Saka score after multiple VAR dramas\n\nHas there ever been a time when the red half of the City has wanted Spurs to avoid defeat more? Probably not, but equally has there ever been a time Tottenham have wanted to see their own side win less? Again, probably not.\n\nYet, Tottenham remains one of the historically trickiest tests that remains for City. They've managed to surrender many points to Spurs despite, prior to this season, having a far comfier time against the Gunners and the hope is they give up just two more.\n\nThe last chance is on the final day with West Ham United travelling to the Etihad Stadium. Striker Michail Antonio has already said that he expects the Gunners to win it if it does go all the way to the final fixture.\n\n\"If it goes down to the last day, I reckon Arsenal wins it,\" he said. \"Last game of the season, we [West Ham] have something to play for as well, we're trying to get into Europe, Man City away.\"\n\nHowever, the reality is that the Hammers might not have anything to play for as European qualification looks incredibly unlikely. Still, behind Arsenal, West Ham have taken the most points off 'Big Six' sides this season with Wolves, but less said about the latter the better.\n\nThey say it is the hope that kills you... but if Man City have taught us anything it is that they simply don't slip up. Arsenal beat Bournemouth 3-0 in Saturday's lunchtime kick-off before the Blues, a few hours later, responded with a 5-1 thumping of Wolves at the Etihad Stadium.\n\nErling Haaland casually helped himself to four goals, taking his tally of league goals for the season to 25, to ensure the Gunners' lead at the top was reduced to just one point. Both sides are refusing to ease off the gas as the finish line approaches.\n\nREAD MORE: City player ratings vs Wolves as Erling Haaland shines\n\nREAD MORE: Erling Haaland brutally cuts down Roy Keane with cutting 13 word response\n\nDespite Arsenal's one-point advantage, the elephant in the room remains City's game in hand. Whatever Arsenal do in their two remaining fixtures against Manchester United and Everton, City are guaranteed to win a fourth successive title if they win each of their three remaining matches.\n\nCity travel to Craven Cottage to face Fulham on Saturday lunchtime before returning to the capital for their game in hand against Tottenham Hotspur three days later. They will then bring their league campaign to a close at home to West Ham on May 19.\n\nOn current form, you would be brave to bet against City winning all of their last three games. Guardiola's side have won each of their last six league outings, plundering 24 goals in the process.\n\nAs part of that sequence, City have scored four goals or more in five of their last six, only taking a step back against Nottingham Forest at the City Ground just over a week ago to record a routine 2-0 win. Despite that, the Blues are now within one goal of matching Arsenal's goal tally of 88.\n\nFurthermore, City's hunger for goals in recent weeks has moved them to within six of matching Arsenal's goal difference; the Londoners currently boast a tally of plus 60 while City's currently stands at plus 54.\n\nThe highest points tally Arsenal can achieve is 89, provided they win their two remaining fixtures; City can reach a maximum of 91 with three wins from their last three games. However, there is a chance both sides could finish level pegging on 89 apiece, should City win two and draw one of their last three.\n\nIn that scenario, the winner of the title will be decided on goal difference, meaning City's recent glut of goals could prove decisive in their quest to retain their crown. The Blues have scored four goals or more on eight occasions in the Premier League this term, achieving that particular feat five times since the March international break.\n\nWith that particular statistic in mind, City have hit top gear at just the right time, threatening to blow just about everyone they come into contact with out of the water. And when you add Haaland's tally of seven goals in his last four league games to the mix, it strengthens City's case all the more.\n\nNothing can be guaranteed in football, not least at this stage of And could the Reds win their final three matches?\n\n\"At the moment, those scales are leaving Liverpool looking up rather than down and nothing is in their hands.\n\n\"The players have chosen the wrong time to go through a blip. It's not the exciting, free-flowing Liverpool we're used to. The usually-reliable Mohamed Salah was relegated to the bench - and had a mysterious touchline argument with Jurgen Klopp, suggesting that all may not be well.\n\n\"At the other end, both of West Ham's goals came from unmarked headers, following on from similar goals conceded against Everton in midweek too.\n\n\"Looking back, the Merseyside derby and now the draw at the London Stadium will likely be pinpointed as where Liverpool lost their way.\n\n\"But Jurgen Klopp remained unfazed by any talk of a title collapse - 'I don't think about it,' he nonchalantly replied in his post-match press conference.\n\n\"And while that is true of Klopp, it will certainly be on the minds of three sets of fans with almost as many games to go. We generated so many chances, we could have gone three, four, five up easily.\"\n\nArteta's men gifted the title to City last season after blowing an eight-point lead in the closing weeks.\n\nBut the Ollie Watkins.\n\nGordon was involved again when his shirt was tugged by Josh Brownhill, earning a 50th minute penalty that Arijanet Muric saved to deny Alexander Isak.\n\nSweden striker Isak made amends five minutes later when he converted Murphy's pass for his 20th league goal this season.\n\nDara O'Shea's 86th minute header was no consolation for bedraggled Burnley.\n\nAt Bramall Lane, fourth bottom Nottingham Forest took a giant step towards survival with a 3-1 win against already-relegated Sheffield United.\n\nGonzalo Montiel brought down Ben Brereton Diaz and the Blades forward picked himself up to lash in the 17th minute penalty.\n\nBut Callum Hudson-Odoi grabbed Forest's equaliser in the 27th minute with a superb strike that curled into the far corner.\n\nRyan Yates 38-match Premier League season.\n\nSwindon were relegated in 1993-94 after allowing 100 goals over 42 games.\n\nForest, awaiting the result of their appeal against a four-point deduction for financial It was important win, obviously, and fantastic to score four goals.\n\n\"It was a difficult game. They can play football so it was not easy but we were solid and we're on a mission.\n\n\"Now focus on the next one. I'm confident but we have to keep going, we have to push and focus.\"\n\nHavertz won't rest in title chase\n\nKai Havertz insisted he will not rest in pursuit of Arsenal's first Premier League crown in 20 years.\n\nThe Gunners' 3-0 win over Bournemouth on Saturday was sealed by goals from Bukayo Saka, Leandro Trossard and Declan Rice.\n\nHavertz won the spot-kick which Saka slotted home to break the deadlock and the German forward is relishing the pressure of the run-in.\n\n\"I really enjoy every second,\" he said. \"Sometimes I feel like I don't even want to have a day off because you're just so excited for the weekend and really want to work with the team.\n\n\"You want to try to get everything out of us to be better prepared and we do that every single day.\"\n\nArsenal blew an eight-point lead over City to gift the title to the Manchester club last season.\n\nBut they have shown few signs of nerves this time, winning four in a row to keep City at bay for now.\n\n\"It's going to be two tough games. We have a lot to play for, we have to win those games and then see where we're going to go,\" Havertz said.\n\nTottenham defence destroys Champions League dream\n\nTottenham are still mathematically alive in the battle for a top-four finish thanks to Aston Villa's 1-0 defeat against Brighton, but a 4-2 defeat at Liverpool realistically ended their hopes of Champions League qualification.\n\nAnge Postecoglou's men have now conceded 13 goals in losing their last four matches and still have the might of Manchester City to face in one of their final three games.\n\nThe collapse is part of a wider worrying trend for the Australian manager after a brilliant start to his reign in north London.\n\nSpurs picked up 26 points in the first 10 games of the season. Gunners supporters know all too well about that.\n\nSpurs have all but lost their chance of a top-four finish after a 13th goal in the last four matches was conceded at Anfield as Liverpool won 4-2. Of course, their match against Manchester City on the penultimate match of both club's respective seasons is the one which rightfully Arsenal will want to see their rivals come away with something.\n\nHowever, the build-up to this game has been about whether Spurs would have something to play for. With Villa nearly out of sight now in the Champions League race, that desire is clearly not one to hang on to.\n\nHowever, many who have been committing Arsenal football fan blasphemy with their want of a Tottenham victory or two can now look at the table gleefully. Their form combined with that of Newcastle United and Chelsea means that Europa League qualification is suddenly in peril.\n\nAll three clubs have played 35 games and have three remaining, with Newcastle within four points of Tottenham and Chelsea within six. Spurs are at home to Burnley this weekend, a side who are in desperate need of a win and have done well to stay in the race for survival by picking up some unlikely points along the way.\n\nChelsea meanwhile have Nottingham Forest and Newcastle have Brighton. Everything flowing, super composed on the ball. We generated so many chances, we could have gone three, four, five up easily.\"\n\nArteta's men gifted the title to City last season after blowing an eight-point lead in the closing weeks.\n\nBut the north Londoners have learned from that meltdown, winning 14 of their 16 league games in 2024 to stay firmly in the hunt.\n\nArsenal travel to Manchester United in their penultimate game next weekend before hosting Everton in what they hope will be a potential title clincher on May 19.\n\nBurnley's hopes of avoiding relegation suffered a huge blow as Newcastle ran riot at Turf Moor.\n\nVincent Kompany's second bottom side are five points from safety, with only two games left to avoid an immediate return to the Championship after last season's promotion.\n\nCallum Wilson put Newcastle ahead with a 19th minute tap-in and Sean Longstaff doubled their advantage in the 35th minute, sliding in to finish off Jacob Murphy's pass.\n\nBruno Guimaraes made it three in the 40th minute with a powerful strike from Anthony Gordon's pass.\n\nGordon is only the second player to score 10 goals and provide 10 assists in the Premier League this season after Aston Villa's Ollie Watkins.\n\nGordon was involved again when his shirt was tugged by Josh Brownhill, earning a 50th minute penalty that Arijanet Muric saved to deny Alexander Isak.\n\nSweden striker Isak made amends five minutes later when he converted Murphy's pass for his 20th league goal this season.\n\nDara O'Shea's 86th minute header was no consolation for bedraggled Burnley.\n\nAt Bramall Lane, fourth bottom Nottingham Forest took a giant step towards survival with a 3-1 win against already-relegated Sheffield United.\n\nGonzalo Montiel brought down Ben Brereton Diaz and the Blades forward picked himself up to lash in the 17th minute penalty.\n\nBut Callum Hudson-Odoi grabbed Forest's equaliser in the 27th minute with a superb strike that curled into the far corner.\n\nRyan Yates slammed in Forest's second from close-range after 51 minutes and Hudson-Odoi curled home in the 65th minute.\n\nThat gave the Blades an unwanted record as the first club to concede 100 goals in a 38-match Premier League season.\n\nSwindon were relegated in 1993-94 after allowing 100 goals over 42 games.\n\nForest, awaiting the result of their appeal against a four-point deduction for financial breaches, are three Listen to the It's All Kicking Off! podcast\n\nJamie Redknapp has insisted Manchester United and Tottenham will 'put on a show' in their respective games against Arsenal and Manchester City, amid questions over 'players' integrity' during the title run in.\n\nArsenal retained their one point lead at the summit after thrashing Bournemouth 3-0 in Saturday's early kick-off.\n\nMeanwhile, Manchester City kept the pressure on the Gunners with a thumping 5-1 win against Wolves at the Etihad.\n\nMikel Arteta's men will want to take the title race to the last day with a win against United at Old Trafford next weekend, while Manchester City travel to Fulham before taking another trip to London against Tottenham a week on Tuesday.\n\nAnd Redknapp believes both Tottenham and United will want to win their matches even if it it helps their rivals clinch the title.\n\nManchester United and Tottenham will both play a role in the title race in the coming ten days\n\nJamie Redknapp says both teams will want to win even if they help their rivals win the big prize\n\nPodcast All episodes EPISODE 83: Listen to the latest episode of 'It's All Kicking Off!' Play on Apple Spotify\n\nSpeaking on Sky Sports, he said: 'There's two interesting sub plots. I look at that game with Manchester United away for arsenal. Conspiracy theorists will say that United would much prefer Arsenal to win it than Man City.\n\n'Tottenham are obviously not going to want to see Arsenal win the league. Then, you start to question footballers' integrity, are they actually going to try, and I've had so many people asking me, well Tottenham are not going to want to try too hard and hand the title to Arsenal.\n\n'I've been in that position as a player, on the last day of the season. But your integrity as a player is questioned all the time.\n\n'But you want to win! It's your personal pride, if you're a Tottenham player playing against Man City, you're going to put on a show, that game's going on Sky Sports, you're going to want to show your best. If you've got anything about you, you're going to show your best.\n\n'Both of them (the games) are massive games, because you're putting the players in a position that's really uncomfortable, because they know if they win they're going to put them in a position to pretty much hand the title to their rivals. All to play for still.'\n\nManchester City could leapfrog Arsenal at the top with wins against Fulham and Tottenham\n\nMicah Richards believes Arsenal will overcome Man United but City will win the title\n\nMeanwhile, Micah Richards believes Arsenal will overcome United and will finish seconds as City will win their three remaining games.\n\n'All the players want to get up for big games, no matter where you are in the table. But for Arsenal - they're a different Arsenal,' Richards said.\n\n'When you looked at Arsenal last season, it was more of 'okay they're playing a certain style.' {"uri": "8110285630", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-03", "time": "21:18:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-03T21:18:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-03T21:18:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/us/premier-league/news/man-city-vs-wolves-prediction-odds-betting-premier-league/4c003b5e4ad964c12348e116", "title": "Man City vs Wolves prediction, odds, betting tips and best bets for Premier League match Saturday", "body": "The Premier League title leaders look to keep hold of their grip on the English top flight as Man City welcome Wolves to the Etihad Stadium on Saturday.\n\nPep Guardiola has won three straight Premier League titles and appears in line for an unprecedented fourth, but the room for error is razor-thin. City control their own destiny in the title race, even as they do not lead the standings, sitting a point behind Arsenal -- it's their game in hand which sees City given the advantage, as their maximum possible points are two higher than the Gunners.\n\nWith just four games remaining in the chase, City must win to keep Arsenal at bay, with the Gunners holding a significant goal differential advantage of seven. Any dropped points would allow Mikel Arteta's side a window in for a late triumph at City's expense.\n\nWolves sit 11th in the table and have little to play for, and it's shown, as their standards have slipped over the last month. They finally ended a seven-match winless run with a 2-1 victory over relegation-threatened Luton Town, but have overall been poor of late, with little natural motivation at hand.\n\nThey do sit as one of just four clubs to beat Man City outright this season, and playing spoiler in the title race would certainly be motivation enough, but it's tough to simply turn the switch back on after having been on the beach for so long.\n\nUSA: Click here to see the latest odds for Man City vs Wolves and bet Premier League matches\n\nMan City have been incredibly consistent down the stretch of seasons under Pep Guardiola, losing just four times in the final six matches of the season under the Spanish boss across his previous seven years in charge. In that time, they've won 33 matches and drawn five, giving him a fantastic 79 percent win rate.\n\nIf you narrow that even further to just the games across the final six fixtures in seasons which Man City won the title, but it was not yet mathematically clinched, Guardiola has won 18 games while drawing just one and losing two -- and in one of those defeats, the title was confirmed shortly after anyways thanks to outside results.\n\nThere's a feeling of inevitability about this title chase, and Wolves are just another club in the way of Guardola's Thanos-like grip on the Premier League. Add in the extra motivation for revenge from the reverse fixture, and this match can only end one way.\n\nOf the three title contenders, Arsenal have been strong in the first half, looking to build and hold a lead, while Liverpool have been second-half warriors, looking as if they've played with fire one too many times. The only side of the three to prove consistent across both halves is Man City, who have the most regular distribution of goals through the first and second 45 minutes of play.\n\nCity this season have scored 41 percent of their goals in the first half, which is right in the middle of the pack for Premier League clubs. Arsenal have scored 46 percent of their goals before the break, just two percentage points off the most in the league (Nottingham Forest, Chelsea, and Aston Villa all tied), while Liverpool have scored a whopping 66 percent of their goals after the break, the wildest second-half distribution in the English top flight.\n\nWolves, for their part, are wildly skewed towards the second half like Liverpool from a goal scoring perspective, but from a concession standpoint they are more evenly distributed, and should be ripe for the picking throughout the match. There's a bit of danger in this selection that one Wolves goal could ruin a half, but with Man City to score in both halves at -175, that would be better for a parlay, while there's far more value in this selection as a standalone pick.\n\nAnnoyingly, the betting market has finally caught up to Phil Foden, sporting minus goal scorer odds for the first time this season. The England star missed the last match against Nottingham Forest due to an illness, and has been in and out of the lineup in Premier League play thanks to Guardiola's decision to leave him largely to the Champions League until their elimination.\n\nBut when Foden is in, he's feasted upon Premier League opponents -- he's scored multiple goals in each of his last two appearances, bagging a hat-trick against Aston Villa and a brace against Brighton. In fact, expand it to all of 2024, and Foden has struck for multiple goals in four of the five Premier League games in which he's scored at all.\n\nThe 23-year-old scored against Wolves last year and has two goals against the club in five appearances. He was a creative force in the defeat earlier this season, but with Erling Haaland struggling for goals, Foden has put those duties aside and become a much more potent finisher towards the latter half of this season.\n\nThis important Premier League match in the larger picture of the title race will be televised in the United States on NBC, with the match also streamed on NBC's dedicated service Peacock. Everything flowing, super composed on the ball. We generated so many chances, we could have gone three, four, five up easily.\"\n\nArteta's men gifted the title to City last season after blowing an eight-point lead in the closing weeks.\n\nBut the north Londoners have learned from that meltdown, winning 14 of their 16 league games in 2024 to stay firmly in the hunt.\n\nArsenal travel to Manchester United in their penultimate game next weekend before hosting Everton in what they hope will be a potential title clincher on May 19.\n\nBurnley's hopes of avoiding relegation suffered a huge blow as Newcastle ran riot at Turf Moor.\n\nVincent the 40th minute with a powerful strike from Anthony Gordon's pass.\n\nGordon is only the second player to score 10 goals and provide 10 assists in the Premier League this season after Aston Villa's Ollie Watkins.\n\nGordon was involved again when his shirt was tugged by Josh Brownhill, earning a 50th minute penalty that Arijanet Muric saved to deny Alexander Isak.\n\nSweden striker Isak made amends five minutes later when he converted Murphy's pass for his 20th league goal this season.\n\nDara O'Shea's 86th minute header was no consolation for bedraggled Burnley.\n\nAt Bramall Lane, fourth bottom Nottingham Forest took a giant step towards survival with a 3-1 win against already-relegated Sheffield United.\n\nGonzalo Montiel brought down Ben Brereton Diaz and the Blades forward picked himself up to lash in the 17th minute penalty.\n\nBut Callum Hudson-Odoi grabbed Forest's equaliser in the 27th minute with a superb strike that curled into the far corner.\n\nRyan Yates slammed in Forest's second from close-range after 51 minutes and Hudson-Odoi curled home in the 65th minute.\n\nThat gave the Blades an unwanted record as the first club to concede 100 goals in a 38-match Premier League season.\n\nSwindon were relegated in 1993-94 after allowing 100 goals over 42 games.\n\nForest, awaiting the result of their appeal against a four-point deduction for financial breaches, are three points ahead of third bottom Luton, who drew 1-1 with Everton on Friday.\n\nWest London rivals Brentford and Fulham shared a dour 0-0 draw.\n\nsmg/dj\n\nMore from this Everything flowing, super composed on the ball. We generated so many chances, we could have gone three, four, five up easily.\"\n\nArteta's men gifted the title to City last season after blowing an eight-point lead in the closing weeks.\n\nBut the season after Aston Villa's Ollie Watkins.\n\nGordon was involved again when his shirt was tugged by Josh Brownhill, earning a 50th minute penalty that Arijanet Muric saved to deny Alexander Isak.\n\nSweden striker Isak made amends five minutes later when he converted Murphy's pass for his 20th league goal this season.\n\nDara O'Shea's 86th minute header was no consolation for bedraggled Burnley.\n\nAt Bramall Lane, fourth bottom Nottingham Forest took a giant step towards survival with a 3-1 win against already-relegated Sheffield United.\n\nGonzalo Montiel brought down Ben Brereton Diaz and the Blades forward picked himself up to lash in the 17th minute penalty.\n\nBut Callum Hudson-Odoi grabbed Forest's equaliser in the 27th minute with a superb strike that curled into the far corner.\n\nRyan Yates slammed in Forest's second from close-range after 51 minutes and Hudson-Odoi curled home in the 65th minute.\n\nThat gave the Blades an unwanted record as the first club to concede 100 goals in a 38-match Premier League season.\n\nSwindon were relegated in 1993-94 after allowing 100 goals over 42 games.\n\nForest, awaiting the result of their appeal against a four-point {"uri": "8112111292", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "09:06:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T09:06:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T09:05:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.90min.com/what-arsenal-man-city-need-win-premier-league-title-saturday-results", "title": "What Arsenal and Man City need to win Premier League title after Saturday's results", "body": "The title race is going down to the wire / Ryan Pierse / Staff / Visionhaus / Contributor\n\nPremier League title rivals Arsenal and Manchester City spent most of Saturday hoping their rivals would slip up, but no such catastrophes arrived as both sides picked up wins at home.\n\nThe Gunners eventually broke through against Bournemouth and ended up running out 3-0 winners at the Emirates Stadium, but the Cityzens showed few signs of feeling the pressure as they routed Wolves 5-1 with Erling Haaland getting on the scoresheet four times.\n\nWith the 2023/24 season approaching its conclusion, here's what Arsenal and Man City need in the final weeks of the campaign to secure the title.\n\nWhile Arsenal remain in top spot after Saturday's victory over Bournemouth in the early kick-off, they still require a slip-up from Man City to claim their first Premier League title since 2003/04.\n\nThe weekend's results mean Mikel Arteta's side still hold a one-point advantage over Pep Guardiola's outfit, who completely trounced Wolves later in the day, but the reigning champions still have a game in hand. If both sides win all their remaining matches, it will be the Cityzens who claim a fourth top-flight championship in a row.\n\nGoal difference is currently in Arsenal's favour, boasting +60 in comparison to Man City's +54, meaning a draw from their rivals would be enough to put the north Londoners in the driving seat.\n\nLiverpool can still technically finish top of the pile but would require major implosions from the current top two to reduce the eight-point gap to the summit.\n\nArsenal's next Premier League fixture is a big one, coming away at Old Trafford when they battle Manchester United. The Gunners and the Red Devils were once fierce rivals at the top of the table but Erik ten Hag's side have endured a disappointing campaign and can only finish fifth at best.\n\nArteta's squad then have a week to prepare for their final game of the season at home against Everton, who have recently secured their place in the top flight despite suffering points deductions throughout the campaign.\n\nMan City, however, have three matches left to fulfil. They play a day before Arsenal when they visit Fulham at Craven Cottage in Gameweek 37 and are then in midweek action with a defining fixture away at Tottenham.
